Verse: ॐ ऐं मार्कण्डेय उवाच॥
Translation: OṀ aiṁ. Mārkaṇḍeya said:

Verse: सावर्णिः सूर्यतनयो यो मनुः कथ्यतेऽष्टमः ।निशामय तदुत्पत्तिं विस्तराद्गदतो मम॥
Translation: Sāvarṇi, who is Sūrya’s son, is called the eighth manu. Listen while I relate the story of his birth

Verse: महामायानुभावेन यथा मन्वन्तराधिपः ।स बभूव महाभागः सावर्णिस्तनयो रवेः॥
Translation: and of how, by Mahāmāyā’s authority, he—the illustrious son of the sun god—came to be the lord of an age.

Verse: स्वारोचिषेऽन्तरे पूर्वं चैत्रवंशसमुद्भवः ।सुरथो नाम राजाभूत्समस्ते क्षितिमण्डले॥
Translation: Long ago in the age of the manu Svarociṣba, there arose from the line of Caitra a king named Suratha, who ruled over the whole earth.

Verse: तस्य पालयतः सम्यक् प्रजाः पुत्रानिवौरसान् ।बभूवुः शत्रवो भूपाः कोलाविध्वंसिनस्तदा॥
Translation: He looked after his subjects justly, as if they were his own children. But there were princes at that time who attacked the native hill tribes and became his enemies.

Verse: तस्य तैरभवद् युद्धमतिप्रबलदण्डिनः ।न्यूनैरपि स तैर्युद्धे कोलाविध्वंसिभिर्जितः॥
Translation: Though mightily armed and resolved to fight against them, he suffered defeat in battle, despite his enemies’ inferior forces.

Verse: ततः स्वपुरमायातो निजदेशाधिपोऽभवत् ।आक्रान्तः स महाभागस्तैस्तदा प्रबलारिभिः॥
Translation: And so, with only his native province left to rule, he returned to his own city. There, powerful adversaries set upon him, the illustrious Suratha,

Verse: अमात्यैर्बलिभिर्दुष्टैर्दुर्बलस्य दुरात्मभिः ।कोशो बलं चापहृतं तत्रापि स्वपुरे ततः॥
Translation: now bereft of strength. His ministers, mighty, corrupted, and disposed to evil, seized power and plundered the treasury, even there in his own city.

Verse: ततो मृगयाव्याजेन हृतस्वाम्यः स भूपतिः ।एकाकी हयमारुह्य जगाम गहनं वनम्॥
Translation: Thus robbed of his dominion, the king mounted his horse on the pretext of hunting and rode off alone into the dense forest.

Verse: स तत्राश्रममद्राक्षीद्द्विजवर्यस्य मेधसः ।प्रशान्तश्वापदाकीर्णं मुनिशिष्योपशोभितम्॥
Translation: He came upon the hermitage of Medhas, chief among the twice-born, and beheld a forest retreat, graced by the sage’s disciples. There he saw beasts once wild now peacefully abiding.

Verse: तस्थौ कञ्चित्स कालं च मुनिना तेन सत्कृतः ।इतश्चेतश्च विचरंस्तस्मिन् मुनिवराश्रमे॥
Translation: Welcomed by the sage, he remained at the hermitage for some time, wandering here and there about the enclosure.

Verse: सोऽचिन्तयत्तदा तत्र ममत्वाकृष्टमानसः ।मत्पूर्वैः पालितं पूर्वं मया हीनं पुरं हि तत्॥
Translation: In that setting, self-centered concerns came to seize his mind, and he reflected:

Verse: मद्भृत्यैस्तैरसद्वृत्तैर्धर्मतः पाल्यते न वा ।न जाने स प्रधानो मे शूरो हस्ती सदामदः॥
Translation: I have left behind the capital that my ancestors governed before me. Are my perverse officials overseeing it justly or not?

Verse: मम वैरिवशं यातः कान् भोगानुपलप्स्यते ।ये ममानुगता नित्यं प्रसादधनभोजनैः॥
Translation: My prized elephant, valiant and of unceasing prowess, has fallen into the hands of my enemies. I know not what comforts he’ll now enjoy.

Verse: अनुवृत्तिं ध्रुवं तेऽद्य कुर्वन्त्यन्यमहीभृताम् ।असम्यग्व्ययशीलैस्तैः कुर्वद्भिः सततं व्ययम्॥
Translation: Those retainers of mine, constantly eager for favor, wealth, and feasting, now surely submit to other lords.

Verse: सञ्चितः सोऽतिदुःखेन क्षयं कोशो गमिष्यति ।एतच्चान्यच्च सततं चिन्तयामास पार्थिवः॥
Translation: Their habitual squandering will soon deplete the wealth I so laboriously amassed.

Verse: तत्र विप्राश्रमाभ्याशे वैश्यमेकं ददर्श सः ।स पृष्टस्तेन कस्त्वं भो हेतुश्चागमनेऽत्र कः॥
Translation: While pondering those and other questions, the king caught sight of a lone merchant approaching the sage’s hermitage.

Verse: सशोक इव कस्मात्त्वं दुर्मना इव लक्ष्यसे ।इत्याकर्ण्य वचस्तस्य भूपतेः प्रणयोदितम्॥
Translation: “Who are you,” he asked, “and what brings you here? Why do you look so sorrowful and dejected?”

Verse: प्रत्युवाच स तं वैश्यः प्रश्रयावनतो नृपम्॥
Translation: Hearing the king speak in friendship, the merchant bowed respectfully and replied.

Verse: वैश्य उवाच॥
Translation: The merchant said:

Verse: समाधिर्नाम वैश्योऽहमुत्पन्नो धनिनां कुले॥
Translation: “I am a merchant named Samādhi, born in a wealthy family. My wife and children grew wicked through avarice and cast me out.

Verse: पुत्रदारैर्निरस्तश्च धनलोभादसाधुभिः ।विहीनश्च धनैर्दारैः पुत्रैरादाय मे धनम्॥
Translation: Destitute of riches, wife, and children, my wealth taken from me, I have arrived in the forest, distressed and forsaken by trusted kinsmen.

Verse: वनमभ्यागतो दुःखी निरस्तश्चाप्तबन्धुभिः ।सोऽहं न वेद्मि पुत्राणां कुशलाकुशलात्मिकाम्॥
Translation: Being here, I know not whether good fortune or ill has befallen my children, wife, and family.

Verse: प्रवृत्तिं स्वजनानां च दाराणां चात्र संस्थितः ।किं नु तेषां गृहे क्षेममक्षेमं किं नु साम्प्रतम्॥
Translation: At present is well-being or misfortune theirs at home?

Verse: कथं ते किं नु सद्वृत्ता दुर्वृत्ताः किं नु मे सुताः॥
Translation: How are my children? Is their behavior virtuous or vile?”

Verse: राजोवाच॥
Translation: The king said:

Verse: यैर्निरस्तो भवाँल्लुब्धैः पुत्रदारादिभिर्धनैः॥
Translation: “Those greedy sons, wife, and others who dispossessed you of your wealth—

Verse: तेषु किं भवतः स्नेहमनुबध्नाति मानसम्॥
Translation: why does your mind still cherish them?”

Verse: वैश्य उवाच॥
Translation: The merchant said:

Verse: एवमेतद्यथा प्राह भवानस्मद्गतं वचः॥
Translation: “Even as you say it, this very thought occurs to me. But what can I do? My heart is not inclined to rancor

Verse: किं करोमि न बध्नाति मम निष्ठुरतां मनः ।यैः सन्त्यज्य पितृस्नेहं धनलुब्धैर्निराकृतः॥
Translation: but still turns with affection to those who drove me away, scorning love for father, husband, and kinsman, out of lust for wealth.

Verse: पतिस्वजनहार्दं च हार्दितेष्वेव मे मनः ।किमेतन्नाभिजानामि जानन्नपि महामते॥
Translation: I recognize this, O wise one. Still, I do not understand how my thoughts are drawn in love to my unworthy kinsfolk.

Verse: यत्प्रेमप्रवणं चित्तं विगुणेष्वपि बन्धुषु ।तेषां कृते मे निःश्वासो दौर्मनस्यं च जायते॥
Translation: Because of them I sigh, overcome with despair.

Verse: करोमि किं यन्न मनस्तेष्वप्रीतिषु निष्ठुरम्॥
Translation: What can I do, since the pain has failed to harden my heart?”

Verse: मार्कण्डेय उवाच॥
Translation: Mārkaṇḍeya said:

Verse: ततस्तौ सहितौ विप्र तं मुनिं समुपस्थितौ॥
Translation: Then together they approached the sage,

Verse: समाधिर्नाम वैश्योऽसौ स च पार्थिवसत्तमः ।कृत्वा तु तौ यथान्यायं यथार्हं तेन संविदम्॥
Translation: that merchant named Samādhi and Suratha, the best of kings.

Verse: उपविष्टौ कथाः काश्चिच्चक्रतुर्वैश्यपार्थिवौ॥
Translation: Having observed the respect that was the sage’s due, the merchant and the king sat down to tell their stories.

Verse: राजोवाच॥
Translation: The king said:

Verse: भगवंस्त्वामहं प्रष्टुमिच्छाम्येकं वदस्व तत्॥
Translation: “Revered sir, I wish to ask you one thing. Please reply.

Verse: दुःखाय यन्मे मनसः स्वचित्तायत्ततां विना ।ममत्वं गतराज्यस्य राज्याङ्गेष्वखिलेष्वपि॥
Translation: Without control of my thoughts, my mind is coming to grief.

Verse: जानतोऽपि यथाज्ञस्य किमेतन्मुनिसत्तम ।अयं च निकृतः पुत्रैर्दारैर्भृत्यैस्तथोज्झितः॥
Translation: I remain possessive toward my lost kingdom and all parts of the realm as if unaware that they are no longer mine. Venerable sage, how can this be?

Verse: स्वजनेन च सन्त्यक्तस्तेषु हार्दी तथाप्यति ।एवमेष तथाहं च द्वावप्यत्यन्तदुःखितौ॥
Translation: And this fellow has been humiliated by his children and wife, deserted by his servants, and forsaken by his own people. Still he feels exceeding affection for them.

Verse: दृष्टदोषेऽपि विषये ममत्वाकृष्टमानसौ ।तत्किमेतन्महाभाग यन्मोहो ज्ञानिनोरपि॥
Translation: It is the same with me. We both are distressed to the utmost, held by attachment to things, even though we see their faults.

Verse: ममास्य च भवत्येषा विवेकान्धस्य मूढता॥
Translation: Venerable sir, how is it that we who should know better can be so deluded? Ours is the perplexity of those who are blind to right understanding.”

Verse: ऋषिरुवाच॥
Translation: The seer said:

Verse: ज्ञानमस्ति समस्तस्य जन्तोर्विषयगोचरे॥
Translation: “Illustrious king, through the perceptions of the senses, every living being has knowledge of the manifest universe. The objects of sense-perception reveal themselves in various ways.

Verse: विषयाश्च महाभाग यान्ति चैवं पृथक्पृथक् ।दिवान्धाः प्राणिनः केचिद्रात्रावन्धास्तथापरे॥
Translation: Some creatures are blind by day, and others are blind by night. Some creatures see equally by day and night.

Verse: केचिद्दिवा तथा रात्रौ प्राणिनस्तुल्यदृष्टयः ।ज्ञानिनो मनुजाः सत्यं किं तु ते न हि केवलम्॥
Translation: Truly, humans are endowed with the power of perception, but they are not alone, for cattle, birds, wild animals, and all other living creatures also perceive.

Verse: यतो हि ज्ञानिनः सर्वे पशुपक्षिमृगादयः ।ज्ञानं च तन्मनुष्याणां यत्तेषां मृगपक्षिणाम्॥
Translation: That awareness which humans have, birds and beasts possess also; and their awareness, humans have, too. In other ways also the two are similar.

Verse: मनुष्याणां च यत्तेषां तुल्यमन्यत्तथोभयोः ।ज्ञानेऽपि सति पश्यैतान् पतङ्गाञ्छावचञ्चुषु॥
Translation: Look at these birds. Though feeling the pangs of hunger, out of delusion they still busy themselves by dropping food into the beaks of their young.

Verse: कणमोक्षादृतान् मोहात्पीड्यमानानपि क्षुधा ।मानुषा मनुजव्याघ्र साभिलाषाः सुतान् प्रति॥
Translation: Illustrious sir, humans long for offspring, surely expecting gratitude in return. Do you not see this?

Verse: लोभात् प्रत्युपकाराय नन्वेतान् किं न पश्यसि ।तथापि ममतावर्त्ते मोहगर्ते निपातिताः॥
Translation: In this very manner they are hurled into the whirlpool of attachment, the pit of delusion, by the power of Mahāmāyā, Who produces the continuing cycle of this transitory world.

Verse: महामायाप्रभावेण संसारस्थितिकारिणा ।तन्नात्र विस्मयः कार्यो योगनिद्रा जगत्पतेः॥
Translation: Do not be astonished. This same Mahāmāyā is Yoganidrā, the meditative sleep of Viṣṇu, the lord of the world. By Her this world is deluded.

Verse: महामाया हरेश्चैषा तया सम्मोह्यते जगत् ।ज्ञानिनामपि चेतांसि देवी भगवती हि सा॥
Translation: She, the blessed Goddess Mahāmāyā, seizes the minds of even the wise and draws them into delusion.

Verse: बलादाकृष्य मोहाय महामाया प्रयच्छति ।तया विसृज्यते विश्वं जगदेतच्चराचरम्॥
Translation: She creates all this universe, moving and unmoving, and it is She Who graciously bestows liberation on humanity.

Verse: सैषा प्रसन्ना वरदा नृणां भवति मुक्तये ।सा विद्या परमा मुक्तेर्हेतुभूता सनातनी॥
Translation: She is the supreme knowledge and the eternal cause of liberation,

Verse: संसारबन्धहेतुश्च सैव सर्वेश्वरेश्वरी॥
Translation: even as She is the cause of bondage to this transitory existence. She is the sovereign of all lords.”

Verse: राजोवाच॥
Translation: The king said:

Verse: भगवन् का हि सा देवी महामायेति यां भवान्॥
Translation: “Revered sir, Who is that Goddess whom you call Mahāmāyā? How did She originate, and in what ways does She Act?

Verse: ब्रवीति कथमुत्पन्ना सा कर्मास्याश्च किं द्विज ।यत्प्रभावा च सा देवी यत्स्वरूपा यदुद्भवा॥
Translation: And whatever Her Glory, this Goddess, whatever Her Form and Origin,

Verse: तत्सर्वं श्रोतुमिच्छामि त्वत्तो ब्रह्मविदां वर॥
Translation: all that I wish to learn from you, who are supreme among the knowers of Brahman.”

Verse: ऋषिरुवाच॥
Translation: The seer said:

Verse: नित्यैव सा जगन्मूर्तिस्तया सर्वमिदं ततम्॥
Translation: “She Is Eternal, having the world as Her Form. She Pervades All This.

Verse: तथापि तत्समुत्पत्तिर्बहुधा श्रूयतां मम ।देवानां कार्यसिद्ध्यर्थमाविर्भवति सा यदा॥
Translation: Yet She Emerges in various ways. Hear it from me.

Verse: उत्पन्नेति तदा लोके सा नित्याप्यभिधीयते ।योगनिद्रां यदा विष्णुर्जगत्येकार्णवीकृते॥
Translation: Although She Is Eternal, when She Manifests to accomplish the purpose of the Gods, She Is said to be Born in the world.

Verse: आस्तीर्य शेषमभजत् कल्पान्ते भगवान् प्रभुः ।तदा द्वावसुरौ घोरौ विख्यातौ मधुकैटभौ॥
Translation: At the end of the cosmic day, when the universe dissolved into the primordial ocean, the blessed lord Viṣṇu stretched out on the serpent Śeṣa and entered into meditative sleep.

Verse: विष्णुकर्णमलोद्भूतौ हन्तुं ब्रह्माणमुद्यतौ ।स नाभिकमले विष्णोः स्थितो ब्रह्मा प्रजापतिः॥
Translation: Then two fearsome asuras, the notorious Madhu and Kaiṭabha, issued forth from the wax in Viṣṇu’s ears, intent on slaying Brahmā,

Verse: दृष्ट्वा तावसुरौ चोग्रौ प्रसुप्तं च जनार्दनम् ।तुष्टाव योगनिद्रां तामेकाग्रहृदयः स्थितः॥
Translation: who was seated on the lotus that grew from Viṣṇu’s navel. When he saw the raging asuras and the sleeping Viṣṇu,

Verse: विबोधनार्थाय हरेर्हरिनेत्रकृतालयाम् ।विश्वेश्वरीं जगद्धात्रीं स्थितिसंहारकारिणीम्॥
Translation: Brahmā could think of nothing but to awaken him, and to that end he extolled Yoganidrā, Who had settled over Viṣṇu’s eyes

Verse: निद्रां भगवतीं विष्णोरतुलां तेजसः प्रभुः॥
Translation: as his blessed sleep. The resplendent lord Brahmā extolled Her Who rules the universe, Who Sustains and Dissolves it. He extolled Her Who Is Incomparable.

Verse: ब्रह्मोवाच॥
Translation: Brahmā said:

Verse: त्वं स्वाहा त्वं स्वधा त्वं हि वषट्कारः स्वरात्मिका॥
Translation: ‘You Are The Mantras of Consecration to the Gods and the ancestors. At Your Bidding They Are Uttered, and they are your very embodiment. You Are The Nectar of Immortality, O Imperishable, Eternal One. Truly, You Abide As The Transcendent Being,

Verse: सुधा त्वमक्षरे नित्ये त्रिधा मात्रात्मिका स्थिता ।अर्धमात्रा स्थिता नित्या यानुच्चार्याविशेषतः॥
Translation: yet in every moment you abide, inseparable and inexpressible, as the eternal source of all becoming. Indeed You Are That. You Are Sāvitrī, the Source of All Purity and Protection; You Are the Supreme Mother of The Gods.

Verse: त्वमेव सन्ध्या सावित्री त्वं देवि जननी परा ।त्वयैतद्धार्यते विश्वं त्वयैतत् सृज्यते जगत्॥
Translation: By You is this universe supported, of You is this world born, by You is it protected, O Devī, and You always Consume it at the end.

Verse: त्वयैतत् पाल्यते देवि त्वमत्स्यन्ते च सर्वदा ।विसृष्टौ सृष्टिरूपा त्वं स्थितिरूपा च पालने॥
Translation: You Are the Creative Force at the World’s Birth and Its Sustenance for as long as it endures. So even at the end of this world, You Appear as Its Dissolution, You Who Encompass it all.

Verse: तथा संहृतिरूपान्ते जगतोऽस्य जगन्मये ।महाविद्या महामाया महामेधा महास्मृतिः॥
Translation: You Are The Great Knowledge and The Great Illusion, The Great Intelligence, The Great Memory and The Great Delusion, The Great Goddess and The Great Demoness.

Verse: महामोहा च भवती महादेवी महेश्वरी ।प्रकृतिस्त्वं च सर्वस्य गुणत्रयविभाविनी॥
Translation: You Are Primordial Matter, Differentiating into the Threefold Qualities of Everything. You Are The Dark Night Of Periodic Dissolution, The Great Night of Final Dissolution, and The Terrifying Night Of Delusion.

Verse: कालरात्रिर्महारात्रिर्मोहरात्रिश्च दारुणा ।त्वं श्रीस्त्वमीश्वरी त्वं ह्रीस्त्वं बुद्धिर्बोधलक्षणा॥
Translation: You Are Radiant Splendor; You Reign Supreme Yet Are Unassuming; You Are The Light Of Understanding. Modesty Are You, And Prosperity, Contentment, Tranquillity and Forbearance.

Verse: लज्जा पुष्टिस्तथा तुष्टिस्त्वं शान्तिः क्षान्तिरेव च ।खड्गिनी शूलिनी घोरा गदिनी चक्रिणी तथा॥
Translation: Armed With Sword And Spear, And With Club And Discus, Waging War With Conch, Bow And Arrows, Sling And Iron Mace, You Inspire Dread.

Verse: शङ्खिनी चापिनी बाणभुशुण्डीपरिघायुधा ।सौम्या सौम्यतराशेषसौम्येभ्यस्त्वतिसुन्दरी॥
Translation: Yet, You Are Pleasing, More Pleasing Than All Else That Is Pleasing, and Exceedingly Beautiful. Transcending Both Highest and Lowest, You Are Indeed The Supreme Sovereign.

Verse: परापराणां परमा त्वमेव परमेश्वरी ।यच्च किञ्चित्क्वचिद्वस्तु सदसद्वाखिलात्मिके॥
Translation: Whatever exists, true or untrue, and wherever it may be, O Soul of Everything, You Are The Power Of All That. How can I praise You?

Verse: तस्य सर्वस्य या शक्तिः सा त्वं किं स्तूयसे मया ।यया त्वया जगत्स्रष्टा जगत्पात्यत्ति यो जगत्॥
Translation: By You, even he Who Creates, Protects, and Devours the world is Subdued with Sleep. Who here can praise You?

Verse: सोऽपि निद्रावशं नीतः कस्त्वां स्तोतुमिहेश्वरः ।विष्णुः शरीरग्रहणमहमीशान एव च॥
Translation: You have caused even Viṣṇu, Śiva, and Me to assume Our embodied forms. Who then can truly praise You?

Verse: कारितास्ते यतोऽतस्त्वां कः स्तोतुं शक्तिमान् भवेत् ।सा त्वमित्थं प्रभावैः स्वैरुदारैर्देवि संस्तुता॥
Translation: Thus Extolled, O Devī, may You with Your Exalted Powers Confound Those Unassailable asuras, Madhu and Kaiṭabha.

Verse: मोहयैतौ दुराधर्षावसुरौ मधुकैटभौ ।प्रबोधं च जगत्स्वामी नीयतामच्युतो लघु॥
Translation: Let Viṣṇu, the lord of the world, be quickly awakened from his slumber

Verse: बोधश्च क्रियतामस्य हन्तुमेतौ महासुरौ॥
Translation: and be roused to slay the two great asuras.’”

Verse: ऋषिरुवाच॥
Translation: The seer said:.’”

Verse: एवं स्तुता तदा देवी तामसी तत्र वेधसा॥
Translation: “Praised thus by the creator to rouse Viṣṇu into slaying Madhu and Kaiṭabha, then and there The Dark Goddess

Verse: विष्णोः प्रबोधनार्थाय निहन्तुं मधुकैटभौ ।नेत्रास्यनासिकाबाहुहृदयेभ्यस्तथोरसः॥
Translation: Emerged from his eyes, mouth, nostrils, arms, heart, and chest, and appeared before Brahmā, Who is born from the Unmanifest.

Verse: निर्गम्य दर्शने तस्थौ ब्रह्मणोऽव्यक्तजन्मनः ।उत्तस्थौ च जगन्नाथस्तया मुक्तो जनार्दनः॥
Translation: And released by Her, Viṣṇu, the Lord of the world, arose from his serpent couch on the undifferentiated ocean and beheld

Verse: एकार्णवेऽहिशयनात्ततः स ददृशे च तौ ।मधुकैटभौ दुरात्मानावतिवीर्यपराक्रमौ॥
Translation: the evil-natured Madhu and Kaiṭabha, exceedingly strong and courageous, seeing red with anger and determined to devour Brahmā.

Verse: क्रोधरक्तेक्षणावत्तुं ब्रह्माणं जनितोद्यमौ ।समुत्थाय ततस्ताभ्यां युयुधे भगवान् हरिः॥
Translation: Then the blessed, all-pervading Viṣṇu rose up and fought with them in hand-to-hand combat for five thousand years.

Verse: पञ्चवर्षसहस्राणि बाहुप्रहरणो विभुः ।तावप्यतिबलोन्मत्तौ महामायाविमोहितौ॥
Translation: And they, mad with the arrogance of power and confounded By Mahāmāyā,

Verse: उक्तवन्तौ वरोऽस्मत्तो व्रियतामिति केशवम्॥
Translation: exclaimed to him, ‘Ask a boon from us! ’

Verse: श्रीभगवानुवाच॥
Translation: The blessed lord Viṣṇu said:

Verse: भवेतामद्य मे तुष्टौ मम वध्यावुभावपि॥
Translation: ‘Since you are pleased with me, so be it. I will surely slay both of you now.

Verse: किमन्येन वरेणात्र एतावद्धि वृतं मया॥
Translation: What other boon is there to ask?”’

Verse: ऋषिरुवाच॥
Translation: The seer said:

Verse: वञ्चिताभ्यामिति तदा सर्वमापोमयं जगत्॥
Translation: “Thus deceived, and beholding that the world consisted entirely of water, they addressed the lotus-eyed Viṣṇu, saying:

Verse: विलोक्य ताभ्यां गदितो भगवान् कमलेक्षणः ।आवां जहि न यत्रोर्वी सलिलेन परिप्लुता॥
Translation: ‘Slay us where water does not flood the earth.’”

Verse: ऋषिरुवाच॥
Translation: The seer said:

Verse: तथेत्युक्त्वा भगवता शङ्खचक्रगदाभृता ।कृत्वा चक्रेण वै छिन्ने जघने शिरसी तयोः॥
Translation: “‘So be it,’ said Viṣṇu, the wielder of conch, discus, and mace. Taking the two of them onto his lap, he cut off their heads with his discus.

Verse: एवमेषा समुत्पन्ना ब्रह्मणा संस्तुता स्वयम् ।प्रभावमस्या देव्यास्तु भूयः शृणु वदामि ते॥
Translation: Thus did The Devī Herself appear when praised by Brahmā. Hear still more of Her Glory, which I will tell you.”

Verse: ॐ ह्रीं ऋषिरुवाच॥
Translation: OṀ hrīṁ. The seer said:

Verse: देवासुरमभूद्युद्धं पूर्णमब्दशतं पुरा ।महिषेऽसुराणामधिपे देवानां च पुरन्दरे॥
Translation: “Long ago, when Mahiṣa was chief of the asuras and Indra was chief of the gods, there was a war between their forces for a full hundred years.

Verse: तत्रासुरैर्महावीर्यैर्देवसैन्यं पराजितम् ।जित्वा च सकलान् देवानिन्द्रोऽभून्महिषासुरः॥
Translation: The valorous asuras vanquished the army of the gods, and after all were conquered, Mahiṣa became the lord of heaven.

Verse: ततः पराजिता देवाः पद्मयोनिं प्रजापतिम् ।पुरस्कृत्य गतास्तत्र यत्रेशगरुडध्वजौ॥
Translation: Then led by Brahmā, the lord of beings, the defeated gods went to Viṣṇu and Śiva

Verse: यथावृत्तं तयोस्तद्वन्महिषासुरचेष्टितम् ।त्रिदशाः कथयामासुर्देवाभिभवविस्तरम्॥
Translation: and related in detail what had happened. The thirty gods told how Mahiṣāsura had wrought their defeat:

Verse: सूर्येन्द्राग्न्यनिलेन्दूनां यमस्य वरुणस्य च ।अन्येषां चाधिकारान्स स्वयमेवाधितिष्ठति॥
Translation: ‘He has usurped the authority of Sūrya, Indra, Agni, Vāyu, and Candra, and of Yama, Varuṇa, and all the others.

Verse: स्वर्गान्निराकृताः सर्वे तेन देवगणा भुवि ।विचरन्ति यथा मर्त्या महिषेण दुरात्मना॥
Translation: Cast out from heaven by the evil Mahiṣa, all the multitudes of gods wander over the earth as mere mortals.

Verse: एतद्वः कथितं सर्वममरारिविचेष्टितम् ।शरणं वः प्रपन्नाः स्मो वधस्तस्य विचिन्त्यताम्॥
Translation: We have related all that this foe of the gods has done, and we seek refuge in You. Be pleased to devise a means for his destruction.’

Verse: इत्थं निशम्य देवानां वचांसि मधुसूदनः ।चकार कोपं शम्भुश्च भ्रुकुटीकुटिलाननौ॥
Translation: When Viṣṇu and Śiva heard the entreaties of the gods, they knit their brows in fury and contorted their faces,

Verse: ततोऽतिकोपपूर्णस्य चक्रिणो वदनात्ततः ।निश्चक्राम महत्तेजो ब्रह्मणः शङ्करस्य च॥
Translation: whereupon a great radiance came forth from Viṣṇu’s rage- filled countenance, and so, too, from Brahmā’s and Śiva’s.

Verse: अन्येषां चैव देवानां शक्रादीनां शरीरतः ।निर्गतं सुमहत्तेजस्तच्चैक्यं समगच्छत॥
Translation: And from Indra’s body and from the bodies of all the other gods, a very great light issued, and it united and became one.

Verse: अतीव तेजसः कूटं ज्वलन्तमिव पर्वतम् ।ददृशुस्ते सुरास्तत्र ज्वालाव्याप्तदिगन्तरम्॥
Translation: The gods saw before them a peak of light like a mountain, blazing brightly and pervading the sky in every direction with its flames.

Verse: अतुलं तत्र तत्तेजः सर्वदेवशरीरजम् ।एकस्थं तदभून्नारी व्याप्तलोकत्रयं त्विषा॥
Translation: Unequaled light, born from the bodies of all the gods, coalesced into a female form and pervaded the three worlds with its splendor.

Verse: यदभूच्छाम्भवं तेजस्तेनाजायत तन्मुखम् ।याम्येन चाभवन् केशा बाहवो विष्णुतेजसा॥
Translation: From Śiva’s light came that which formed the Devī’s face. Yama’s radiance formed Her hair, and Viṣṇu’s effulgence became Her arms.

Verse: सौम्येन स्तनयोर्युग्मं मध्यं चैन्द्रेण चाभवत् ।वारुणेन च जङ्घोरू नितम्बस्तेजसा भुवः॥
Translation: The moon god’s soft light formed Her breasts, and Indra’s brilliance became Her waist. Varuṇa’s light became Her legs, and earth’s splendor formed Her hips.

Verse: ब्रह्मणस्तेजसा पादौ तदङ्गुल्योऽर्कतेजसा ।वसूनां च कराङ्गुल्यः कौबेरेण च नासिका॥
Translation: Her feet took shape from Brahmā’s light and Her toes from Sürya’s brilliance. From the Vasus’ light Her fingers formed and from Kubera’s light, Her nose.

Verse: तस्यास्तु दन्ताः सम्भूताः प्राजापत्येन तेजसा ।नयनत्रितयं जज्ञे तथा पावकतेजसा॥
Translation: From Prajāpati’s lustre came Her teeth, and from Agni’s radiance Her three eyes were born.

Verse: भ्रुवौ च सन्ध्ययोस्तेजः श्रवणावनिलस्य च ।अन्येषां चैव देवानां सम्भवस्तेजसां शिवा॥
Translation: Dawn and dusk became Her eyebrows, the wind god’s splendor shaped Her ears, and all else born of the other gods’ light shone too as the auspicious Devī.

Verse: ततः समस्तदेवानां तेजोराशिसमुद्भवाम् ।तां विलोक्य मुदं प्रापुरमरा महिषार्दिताः ।ततो देवा ददुस्तस्यै स्वानि स्वान्यायुधानि च॥
Translation: Then, beholding Her who appeared from out of their amassed light, all those gods, tormented by Mahiṣa, rejoiced.

Verse: शूलं शूलाद्विनिष्कृष्य ददौ तस्यै पिनाकधृक् ।चक्रं च दत्तवान् कृष्णः समुत्पाट्य स्वचक्रतः॥
Translation: Then the gods bestowed on Her their own weapons and adornments. From his trident Śiva drew forth another and gave it to Her,

Verse: शङ्खं च वरुणः शक्तिं ददौ तस्यै हुताशनः ।मारुतो दत्तवांश्चापं बाणपूर्णे तथेषुधी॥
Translation: and Viṣṇu bestowed a discus spun out from his own. Varuṇa gave Her a conch; and Agni, the eater of oblations, gave Her a spear.

Verse: वज्रमिन्द्रः समुत्पाट्य कुलिशादमराधिपः ।ददौ तस्यै सहस्राक्षो घण्टामैरावताद्गजात्॥
Translation: Vāyu, the wind god, presented a bow and two quivers filled with arrows. Extracting a thunderbolt from his own, Indra, the lord of the immortals,

Verse: कालदण्डाद्यमो दण्डं पाशं चाम्बुपतिर्ददौ ।प्रजापतिश्चाक्षमालां ददौ ब्रह्मा कमण्डलुम्॥
Translation: the all-seeing one, gave it to Her along with a bell from his elephant Airāvata. From his staff of death Yama produced another staff, and Varuṇa, the lord of waters, gave a noose.

Verse: समस्तरोमकूपेषु निजरश्मीन् दिवाकरः ।कालश्च दत्तवान् खड्गं तस्यै चर्म च निर्मलम्॥
Translation: Brahmā, the lord of beings, gave prayer beads and an ascetic’s waterpot. Sūrya, the bringer of day, bestowed his rays of sunlight on all the pores of Her skin;

Verse: क्षीरोदश्चामलं हारमजरे च तथाम्बरे ।चूडामणिं तथा दिव्यं कुण्डले कटकानि च॥
Translation: and Kāla, the lord of time, presented a sword and shining shield. The ocean of milk bestowed a necklace of flawless pearls, ever-new garments,

Verse: अर्धचन्द्रं तथा शुभ्रं केयूरान् सर्वबाहुषु ।नूपुरौ विमलौ तद्वद् ग्रैवेयकमनुत्तमम्॥
Translation: a celestial crest-jewel, earrings, and bracelets, a radiant crescent-shaped ornament, armlets for all Her arms,

Verse: अङ्गुलीयकरत्नानि समस्तास्वङ्गुलीषु च ।विश्वकर्मा ददौ तस्यै परशुं चातिनिर्मलम्॥
Translation: a pair of shining anklets, a necklace beyond compare, and bejeweled rings for all Her fingers.

Verse: अस्त्राण्यनेकरूपाणि तथाभेद्यं च दंशनम् ।अम्लानपङ्कजां मालां शिरस्युरसि चापराम्॥
Translation: Viśvakarman gave Her a gleaming ax, weapons of all kinds, and impenetrable armor.

Verse: अददज्जलधिस्तस्यै पङ्कजं चातिशोभनम् ।हिमवान् वाहनं सिंहं रत्नानि विविधानि च॥
Translation: Garlands of unfading lotuses for Her head and breast the ocean gave to Her, and yet another magnificent lotus to grace Her hand.

Verse: ददावशून्यं सुरया पानपात्रं धनाधिपः ।शेषश्च सर्वनागेशो महामणिविभूषितम्॥
Translation: Himālaya, the lord of mountains, gave Her a lion to ride upon and jewels of many kinds; and Kubera, the lord of wealth, presented a drinking vessel ever-brimming with wine.

Verse: नागहारं ददौ तस्यै धत्ते यः पृथिवीमिमाम् ।अन्यैरपि सुरैर्देवी भूषणैरायुधैस्तथा॥
Translation: Śeṣa, the lord of serpents, who supports this earth, gave Her a garland of snakes, adorned with precious gems.

Verse: सम्मानिता ननादोच्चैः साट्टहासं मुहुर्मुहुः ।तस्या नादेन घोरेण कृत्स्नमापूरितं नभः॥
Translation: Honored also by the other gods with adornments and weapons, the Devī laughed thunderously and defiantly again and again.

Verse: अमायतातिमहता प्रतिशब्दो महानभूत् ।चुक्षुभुः सकला लोकाः समुद्राश्च चकम्पिरे॥
Translation: She filled the entire sky with Her terrible roar, and from the immeasurable din a great echo resounded.

Verse: चचाल वसुधा चेलुः सकलाश्च महीधराः ।जयेति देवाश्च मुदा तामूचुः सिंहवाहिनीम्॥
Translation: All the worlds shook, and the oceans churned. The earth quaked, and the mountains heaved.

Verse: तुष्टुवुर्मुनयश्चैनां भक्तिनम्रात्ममूर्तयः ।दृष्ट्वा समस्तं सङ्क्षुब्धं त्रैलोक्यममरारयः॥
Translation: In joy the gods exclaimed, ‘Victory! ’ to the lion-mounted Devī; and with bodies bowed in devotion, the sages praised Her.

Verse: सन्नद्धाखिलसैन्यास्ते समुत्तस्थुरुदायुधाः ।आः किमेतदिति क्रोधादाभाष्य महिषासुरः॥
Translation: When the enemies of the gods saw the three worlds in upheaval, they readied all their forces for battle and rose up as one, with weapons held high.

Verse: अभ्यधावत तं शब्दमशेषैरसुरैर्वृतः ।स ददर्श ततो देवीं व्याप्तलोकत्रयां त्विषा॥
Translation: ‘Aha! What is this?’ Mahiṣāsura bellowed in wrath. Surrounded by countless asuras, he rushed toward the sound

Verse: पादाक्रान्त्या नतभुवं किरीटोल्लिखिताम्बराम् ।क्षोभिताशेषपातालां धनुर्ज्यानिःस्वनेन ताम्॥
Translation: and then beheld the Devī, who pervaded the three worlds with Her radiance, bending the earth under Her tread, scraping the sky with Her diadem,

Verse: दिशो भुजसहस्रेण समन्ताद्व्याप्य संस्थिताम् ।ततः प्रववृते युद्धं तया देव्या सुरद्विषाम्॥
Translation: shaking all the nether regions with the resonance of Her bowstring, and standing there, penetrating every direction with Her thousand arms.

Verse: शस्त्रास्त्रैर्बहुधा मुक्तैरादीपितदिगन्तरम् ।महिषासुरसेनानीश्चिक्षुराख्यो महासुरः॥
Translation: Thereupon, the battle began between the Devī and the enemies of the gods. Swords and missiles, hurled in every direction, lit up the quarters of the sky.

Verse: युयुधे चामरश्चान्यैश्चतुरङ्गबलान्वितः ।रथानामयुतैः षड्भिरुदग्राख्यो महासुरः॥
Translation: Mahiṣāsura’s general, the great asura named Cikṣura, battled there, and Cāmara led cavalry, charioteers, elephant-drivers, and foot soldiers.

Verse: अयुध्यतायुतानां च सहस्रेण महाहनुः ।पञ्चाशद्भिश्च नियुतैरसिलोमा महासुरः॥
Translation: The great asura called Udagra commanded sixty thousand chariots, Mahāhanu gave battle with his ten million,

Verse: अयुतानां शतैः षड्भिर्बाष्कलो युयुधे रणे ।गजवाजिसहस्रौघैरनेकैः परिवारितः॥
Translation: and the mighty Asiloman fought with forces fifty million strong. With sixty million Bāṣkala fought in the conflict.

Verse: वृतो रथानां कोट्या च युद्धे तस्मिन्नयुध्यत ।बिडालाख्योऽयुतानां च पञ्चाशद्भिरथायुतैः॥
Translation: Encircled by streaming multitudes of elephants and horses, Parivārita fought in that battle with ten million chariots,

Verse: युयुधे संयुगे तत्र रथानां परिवारितः ।अन्ये च तत्रायुतशो रथनागहयैर्वृताः॥
Translation: and he who is called Biḍāla, with five billion chariots surrounding him, engaged in combat there.

Verse: युयुधुः संयुगे देव्या सह तत्र महासुराः ।कोटिकोटिसहस्रैस्तु रथानां दन्तिनां तथा॥
Translation: Amid chariots, elephants, and horses, myriads of other great asuras battled with the Devī,

Verse: हयानां च वृतो युद्धे तत्राभून्महिषासुरः ।तोमरैर्भिन्दिपालैश्च शक्तिभिर्मुसलैस्तथा॥
Translation: their countless chariots, elephants, and horses surrounding Māhiṣāsura there in the fray.

Verse: युयुधुः संयुगे देव्या खड्गैः परशुपट्टिशैः ।केचिच्च चिक्षिपुः शक्तीः केचित् पाशांस्तथापरे॥
Translation: With lances and javelins, spears and clubs, swords and axes, and sharp-edged spears, they fought with the Devī.

Verse: देवीं खड्गप्रहारैस्तु ते तां हन्तुं प्रचक्रमुः ।सापि देवी ततस्तानि शस्त्राण्यस्त्राणि चण्डिका॥
Translation: Some hurled spears while others threw nooses; intent on killing Her, they began an assault with their swords.

Verse: लीलयैव प्रचिच्छेद निजशस्त्रास्त्रवर्षिणी ।अनायस्तानना देवी स्तूयमाना सुरर्षिभिः॥
Translation: But She, the Devī Caṇḍikā, showered down all manner of weapons and cut through their armaments as if in play.

Verse: मुमोचासुरदेहेषु शस्त्राण्यस्त्राणि चेश्वरी ।सोऽपि क्रुद्धो धुतसटो देव्या वाहनकेसरी॥
Translation: Praised by gods and seers, She remained serene, even while unleashing Her weapons at the asuras’ bodies.

Verse: चचारासुरसैन्येषु वनेष्विव हुताशनः ।निःश्वासान् मुमुचे यांश्च युध्यमाना रणेऽम्बिका॥
Translation: Her lion-mount, shaking its mane in fury, stalked among the demon throngs as fire rages through a Forest.

Verse: त एव सद्यः सम्भूता गणाः शतसहस्रशः ।युयुधुस्ते परशुभिर्भिन्दिपालासिपट्टिशैः॥
Translation: The sighs that Ambikā heaved while fighting became at once Her legions by the hundreds and thousands.

Verse: नाशयन्तोऽसुरगणान् देवीशक्त्युपबृंहिताः ।अवादयन्त पटहान् गणाः शङ्खांस्तथापरे॥
Translation: They fought with axes, javelins, swords, and sharp- edged spears, and drawing strength from Her power, they destroyed the demon hordes.

Verse: मृदङ्गांश्च तथैवान्ये तस्मिन् युद्धमहोत्सवे ।ततो देवी त्रिशूलेन गदया शक्तिवृष्टिभिः॥
Translation: Some of Her throngs beat war drums resoundingly, some blew conches, and others drummed upon tabors in their zest for battle.

Verse: खड्गादिभिश्च शतशो निजघान महासुरान् ।पातयामास चैवान्यान् घण्टास्वनविमोहितान्॥
Translation: Then the Devī, with Her trident, club, and volleys of spears, with Her swords and other weapons, slew great asuras by the hundreds

Verse: असुरान् भुवि पाशेन बद्ध्वा चान्यानकर्षयत् ।केचिद् द्विधाकृतास्तीक्ष्णैः खड्गपातैस्तथापरे॥
Translation: and brought down still more with the confounding din of Her bell. Binding other asuras with Her noose, She dragged them along the ground.

Verse: विपोथिता निपातेन गदया भुवि शेरते ।वेमुश्च केचिद्रुधिरं मुसलेन भृशं हताः॥
Translation: Her swordstrokes slashed others in two, while crushing blows from Her mace brought still more down,

Verse: केचिन्निपतिता भूमौ भिन्नाः शूलेन वक्षसि ।निरन्तराः शरौघेण कृताः केचिद्रणाजिरे॥
Translation: and those bludgeoned by Her club vomited forth blood. Others fell to the ground, pierced through the chest by Her trident.

Verse: श्येनानुकारिणः प्राणान् मुमुचुस्त्रिदशार्दनाः ।केषाञ्चिद् बाहवश्छिन्नाश्छिन्नग्रीवास्तथापरे॥
Translation: Her steady stream of arrows made some on that battlefield resemble bristling porcupines, and those tormenters of the gods breathed their last.

Verse: शिरांसि पेतुरन्येषामन्ये मध्ये विदारिताः ।विच्छिन्नजङ्घास्त्वपरे पेतुरुर्व्यां महासुराः॥
Translation: Some had their arms severed, others their necks broken. The heads of others rolled, and still others had their bodies ripped apart.

Verse: एकबाह्वक्षिचरणाः केचिद्देव्या द्विधाकृताः ।छिन्नेऽपि चान्ये शिरसि पतिताः पुनरुत्थिताः॥
Translation: Great asuras, their legs cut from under them, toppled to the ground. Some, severed lengthwise by the Devī, were left one-armed, one-eyed, one-legged.

Verse: कबन्धा युयुधुर्देव्या गृहीतपरमायुधाः ।ननृतुश्चापरे तत्र युद्धे तूर्यलयाश्रिताः॥
Translation: While others there in the battle danced to the throbbing drums, those that She decapitated fell and rose again,

Verse: कबन्धाश्छिन्नशिरसः खड्गशक्त्यृष्टिपाणयः ।तिष्ठ तिष्ठेति भाषन्तो देवीमन्ये महासुराः॥
Translation: headless bodies, still grasping swords, spears, and lances in hand. ‘Stop! Stop!’ other great asuras cried out to the Devī.

Verse: पातितै रथनागाश्वैरसुरैश्च वसुन्धरा ।अगम्या साभवत्तत्र यत्राभूत् स महारणः॥
Translation: Where that great battle raged, the earth was impassable with fallen chariots, elephants, horses, and corpses.

Verse: शोणितौघा महानद्यः सद्यस्तत्र प्रसुस्रुवुः ।मध्ये चासुरसैन्यस्य वारणासुरवाजिनाम्॥
Translation: Torrents of blood, like mighty rivers, gushed from elephants, asuras, and horses there in the midst of the demon army.

Verse: क्षणेन तन्महासैन्यमसुराणां तथाम्बिका ।निन्ये क्षयं यथा वह्निस्तृणदारुमहाचयम्॥
Translation: In an instant, Ambikā led that vast legion of foes to its destruction, as quickly as fire consumes a heap of straw and wood.

Verse: स च सिंहो महानादमुत्सृजन् धुतकेसरः ।शरीरेभ्योऽमरारीणामसूनिव विचिन्वति॥
Translation: And Her lion, roaring thunderously and shaking its mane, prowled about in search of life- breath still issuing from the enemies’ bodies.

Verse: देव्या गणैश्च तैस्तत्र कृतं युद्धं तथासुरैः ।यथैषां तुतुषुर्देवाः पुष्पवृष्टिमुचो दिवि॥
Translation: So did the Devī’s hosts wage war against the asuras. So also did the gods in heaven shower down flowers in praise.”

Verse: ॐ ऋषिरुवाच॥
Translation: The seer said:

Verse: निहन्यमानं तत्सैन्यमवलोक्य महासुरः ।सेनानीश्चिक्षुरः कोपाद्ययौ योद्धुमथाम्बिकाम्॥
Translation: “Now when he saw the army being slaughtered, Cikṣura, the great asura general, went forth in fury to battle with Ambikā.

Verse: स देवीं शरवर्षेण ववर्ष समरेऽसुरः ।यथा मेरुगिरेः शृङ्गं तोयवर्षेण तोयदः॥
Translation: He rained showers of arrows on the Devī in the combat, just as a raincloud showers the summit of Mount Meru.

Verse: तस्य छित्वा ततो देवी लीलयैव शरोत्करान् ।जघान तुरगान्बाणैर्यन्तारं चैव वाजिनाम्॥
Translation: But easily shattering his volley, the Devī killed his steeds and charioteer with Her arrows.

Verse: चिच्छेद च धनुः सद्यो ध्वजं चातिसमुच्छृतम् ।विव्याध चैव गात्रेषु छिन्नधन्वानमाशुगैः॥
Translation: Like lightning, She slashed through his bow and highflying banner. Having destroyed his bow, She wounded him in the limbs with Her swift arrows.

Verse: सच्छिन्नधन्वा विरथो हताश्वो हतसारथिः ।अभ्यधावत तां देवीं खड्गचर्मधरोऽसुरः॥
Translation: With bow broken, chariot wrecked, and horses and charioteer slain, the asura, armed with sword and shield, rushed at the Devī.

Verse: सिंहमाहत्य खड्गेन तीक्ष्णधारेण मूर्धनि ।आजघान भुजे सव्ये देवीमप्यतिवेगवान्॥
Translation: First striking Her lion on the head with his sharp-edged sword, he violently struck the Devī’s left arm.

Verse: तस्याः खड्गो भुजं प्राप्य पफाल नृपनन्दन ।ततो जग्राह शूलं स कोपादरुणलोचनः॥
Translation: O king, as soon as the sword touched Her, it shattered. Then, the great asura, his eyes red with rage, seized his blazing lance

Verse: चिक्षेप च ततस्तत्तु भद्रकाल्यां महासुरः ।जाज्वल्यमानं तेजोभी रविबिम्बमिवाम्बरात्॥
Translation: and flung it at Bhadrakālī, as though he were hurling the very sun from the sky.

Verse: दृष्ट्वा तदापतच्छूलं देवी शूलममुञ्चत ।तेन तच्छतधा नीतं शूलं स च महासुरः॥
Translation: Seeing it approach, the Devī released Her lance and shattered the great asura and his weapon into a hundred pieces.

Verse: हते तस्मिन्महावीर्ये महिषस्य चमूपतौ ।आजगाम गजारूढश्चामरस्त्रिदशार्दनः॥
Translation: When Mahiṣa’s mighty general lay slain, Cāmara, the afflictor of the gods, advanced, mounted on an elephant.

Verse: सोऽपि शक्तिं मुमोचाथ देव्यास्तामम्बिका द्रुतम् ।हुङ्काराभिहतां भूमौ पातयामास निष्प्रभाम्॥
Translation: He dispatched his spear toward the Devī. Quickly Ambikā’s contemptuous outcry sent it hurtling powerless to the ground.

Verse: भग्नां शक्तिं निपतितां दृष्ट्वा क्रोधसमन्वितः ।चिक्षेप चामरः शूलं बाणैस्तदपि साच्छिनत्॥
Translation: Seeing it fallen and shattered, the enraged Cāmara flung a lance, and that, too, She destroyed with Her arrows.

Verse: ततः सिंहः समुत्पत्य गजकुम्भान्तरे स्थितः ।बाहुयुद्धेन युयुधे तेनोच्चैस्त्रिदशारिणा॥
Translation: Her lion then leapt up and, astride the elephant’s forehead, engaged fiercely in direct combat with the enemy of the gods.

Verse: युध्यमानौ ततस्तौ तु तस्मान्नागान्महीं गतौ ।युयुधातेऽतिसंरब्धौ प्रहारैरतिदारुणैः॥
Translation: Struggling, the two fell from the elephant to the ground, still locked in dreadful combat.

Verse: ततो वेगात् खमुत्पत्य निपत्य च मृगारिणा ।करप्रहारेण शिरश्चामरस्य पृथक् कृतम्॥
Translation: In a flash the lion sprang skyward, then alighted and severed Cāmara’s head with a single blow of its paw.

Verse: उदग्रश्च रणे देव्या शिलावृक्षादिभिर्हतः ।दन्तमुष्टितलैश्चैव करालश्च निपातितः॥
Translation: In the fighting the Devī assailed the asura Udagra with rocks and trees; and biting, punching, and slapping Karāla, She felled him, too.

Verse: देवी क्रुद्धा गदापातैश्चूर्णयामास चोद्धतम् ।बाष्कलं भिन्दिपालेन बाणैस्ताम्रं तथान्धकम्॥
Translation: Enraged, the Devī crushed Uddhata to a pulp with the blows of Her mace. She killed Bāṣkala with Her javelin and Tāmra and Andhaka with Her arrows,

Verse: उग्रास्यमुग्रवीर्यं च तथैव च महाहनुम् ।त्रिनेत्रा च त्रिशूलेन जघान परमेश्वरी॥
Translation: and with Her trident the supreme three-eyed Goddess slew Ugrāsya, Ugravīrya, and also Mahāhanu.

Verse: बिडालस्यासिना कायात् पातयामास वै शिरः ।दुर्धरं दुर्मुखं चोभौ शरैर्निन्ये यमक्षयम्॥
Translation: With Her sword She struck Biḍāla’s head from his body, and with Her arrows She dispatched both Durdhara and Durmukha to the abode of death.

Verse: एवं सङ्क्षीयमाणे तु स्वसैन्ये महिषासुरः ।माहिषेण स्वरूपेण त्रासयामास तान् गणान्॥
Translation: While his army thus met destruction, Mahiṣāsura terrified the Devī’s hosts with his own buffalo form,

Verse: कांश्चित्तुण्डप्रहारेण खुरक्षेपैस्तथापरान् ।लाङ्गूलताडितांश्चान्यान् शृङ्गाभ्यां च विदारितान्॥
Translation: jostling some with his snout and pawing others with his hooves. Others he lashed with his tail and lacerated with his horns.

Verse: वेगेन कांश्चिदपरान्नादेन भ्रमणेन च ।निःश्वासपवनेनान्यान्पातयामास भूतले॥
Translation: He toppled some of them to the ground with the unleashed force of his bellowing and wheeling about, and the blast of his breath brought still others down.

Verse: निपात्य प्रमथानीकमभ्यधावत सोऽसुरः ।सिंहं हन्तुं महादेव्याः कोपं चक्रे ततोऽम्बिका॥
Translation: After destroying the great Goddess’s forces, Mahiṣāsura rushed forward to slay Her lion. At that, Ambikā became enraged.

Verse: सोऽपि कोपान्महावीर्यः खुरक्षुण्णमहीतलः ।शृङ्गाभ्यां पर्वतानुच्चांश्चिक्षेप च ननाद च॥
Translation: But Mahiṣāsura, great in valor, struck the earth angrily with his hooves, flung mountains skyward with his horns, and bellowed frightfully.

Verse: वेगभ्रमणविक्षुण्णा मही तस्य व्यशीर्यत ।लाङ्गूलेनाहतश्चाब्धिः प्लावयामास सर्वतः॥
Translation: Under his frenzied wheeling, the trampled earth broke apart. Lashed by his tail, the ocean overflowed all around.

Verse: धुतशृङ्गविभिन्नाश्च खण्डं खण्डं ययुर्घनाः ।श्वासानिलास्ताः शतशो निपेतुर्नभसोऽचलाः॥
Translation: Thrashed by his horns, the clouds fragmented and dispersed. Tossed about on his blasting breath, mountains by the hundreds fell from the sky.

Verse: इति क्रोधसमाध्मातमापतन्तं महासुरम् ।दृष्ट्वा सा चण्डिका कोपं तद्वधाय तदाकरोत्॥
Translation: When She saw the great asura approaching, inflated with rage, Caṇḍikā aroused Her wrath and prepared to slay him.

Verse: सा क्षिप्त्वा तस्य वै पाशं तं बबन्ध महासुरम् ।तत्याज माहिषं रूपं सोऽपि बद्धो महामृधे॥
Translation: She threw Her noose over him and bound him. Fettered thus in the fierce battle, the great asura left his buffalo form

Verse: ततः सिंहोऽभवत्सद्यो यावत्तस्याम्बिका शिरः ।छिनत्ति तावत् पुरुषः खड्गपाणिरदृश्यत॥
Translation: and assumed the shape of a lion. No sooner had Ambikā severed his head than he appeared as a man with sword in hand.

Verse: तत एवाशु पुरुषं देवी चिच्छेद सायकैः ।तं खड्गचर्मणा सार्धं ततः सोऽभून्महागजः॥
Translation: Instantly, with Her arrows the Devī cut him to shreds along with his sword and shield. Then he took the form of a great elephant

Verse: करेण च महासिंहं तं चकर्ष जगर्ज च ।कर्षतस्तु करं देवी खड्गेन निरकृन्तत॥
Translation: and dragged Her mighty lion along with his trunk, but while he trumpeted loudly, the Devī chopped off his trunk with Her sword.

Verse: ततो महासुरो भूयो माहिषं वपुरास्थितः ।तथैव क्षोभयामास त्रैलोक्यं सचराचरम्॥
Translation: Once more the great asura assumed his buffalo form and caused the three worlds, with all that is moving and unmoving, to tremble.

Verse: ततः क्रुद्धा जगन्माता चण्डिका पानमुत्तमम् ।पपौ पुनः पुनश्चैव जहासारुणलोचना॥
Translation: Angered, Caṇḍikā, the Mother of the worlds, drank a divine potion, and with eyes reddened She laughed again and again.

Verse: ननर्द चासुरः सोऽपि बलवीर्यमदोद्धतः ।विषाणाभ्यां च चिक्षेप चण्डिकां प्रति भूधरान्॥
Translation: The asura bellowed in return, intoxicated with his own might and valor, and with his horns he hurled mountains at Caṇḍikā.

Verse: सा च तान्प्रहितांस्तेन चूर्णयन्ती शरोत्करैः ।उवाच तं मदोद्धूतमुखरागाकुलाक्षरम्॥
Translation: Her volley of arrows reduced them to dust. Her face flushed with inebriation from the divine drink, and She addressed him excitedly.

Verse: देव्युवाच॥
Translation: The Devī said:

Verse: गर्ज गर्ज क्षणं मूढ मधु यावत्पिबाम्यहम् ।मया त्वयि हतेऽत्रैव गर्जिष्यन्त्याशु देवताः॥
Translation: ‘Bellow, you fool, bellow for now while I drink this potion. After I have slain you, the gods will cheer in this very place.”’

Verse: ऋषिरुवाच॥
Translation: The seer said:

Verse: एवमुक्त्वा समुत्पत्य सारूढा तं महासुरम् ।पादेनाक्रम्य कण्ठे च शूलेनैनमताडयत्॥
Translation: “Having declared that, She leapt upon the great asura, pinned his neck down with Her foot, and pierced him through with Her spear.

Verse: ततः सोऽपि पदाक्रान्तस्तया निजमुखात्तदा ।अर्धनिष्क्रान्त एवासीद्देव्या वीर्येण संवृतः॥
Translation: Trapped there under the Devī’s foot and crushed by Her might, he emerged half-way in his true form from his buffalo mouth.

Verse: अर्धनिष्क्रान्त एवासौ युध्यमानो महासुरः ।तया महासिना देव्या शिरश्छित्त्वा निपातितः॥
Translation: Half-revealed and fighting still, that great asura fell to the Devī, beheaded by Her great sword.

Verse: ततो हाहाकृतं सर्वं दैत्यसैन्यं ननाश तत् ।प्रहर्षं च परं जग्मुः सकला देवतागणाः॥
Translation: Then crying out in alarm, the whole demon army perished, and all the divine hosts exulted.

Verse: तुष्टुवुस्तां सुरा देवीं सहदिव्यैर्महर्षिभिः ।जगुर्गन्धर्वपतयो ननृतुश्चाप्सरोगणाः॥
Translation: Together with the great heavenly seers the gods praised the Devī, the celestial musicians sang, and throngs of cloud-nymphs danced.”

Verse: ॐ ऋषिरुवाच॥
Translation: The seer said:

Verse: शक्रादयः सुरगणा निहतेऽतिवीर्ये तस्मिन्दुरात्मनि सुरारिबले च देव्या । तां तुष्टुवुः प्रणतिनम्रशिरोधरांसा वाग्भिः प्रहर्षपुलकोद्गमचारुदेहाः॥
Translation: “When the Devī had struck down the brave but wicked Mahiṣāsura and his army of the Gods’ foes, Indra and the hosts of Gods lifted their voices to Her in praise, their heads bowed in reverence, their bodies made beautiful by the thrill of rapture.

Verse: देव्या यया ततमिदं जगदात्मशक्त्या निःशेषदेवगणशक्तिसमूहमूर्त्या । तामम्बिकामखिलदेवमहर्षिपूज्यां भक्त्या नताः स्म विदधातु शुभानि सा नः॥
Translation: ‘To the Devī, Who spreads out this world through Her own power and Who embodies Herself as all the powers of the hosts of Gods; to Ambikā, Who is worthy of

Verse: यस्याः प्रभावमतुलं भगवाननन्तो ब्रह्मा हरश्च न हि वक्तुमलं बलं च । सा चण्डिकाखिलजगत्परिपालनाय नाशाय चाशुभभयस्य मतिं करोतु॥
Translation: May She whose unequalled might and splendor even the blessed Viṣṇu, Brahmā, and Śiva are powerless to describe, may She, Caṇḍikā, be intent on protecting all the world and on destroying the fear of misfortune.

Verse: या श्रीः स्वयं सुकृतिनां भवनेष्वलक्ष्मीः पापात्मनां कृतधियां हृदयेषु बुद्धिः । श्रद्धा सतां कुलजनप्रभवस्य लज्जा तां त्वां नताः स्म परिपालय देवि विश्वम्॥
Translation: O Devī, we bow before You Who are yourself good fortune in the dwellings of the virtuous and misfortune in the abodes of the wicked, intelligence in the hearts of the learned, faith in the hearts of the good, and modesty in the hearts of the high-born. May You protect the universe!

Verse: किं वर्णयाम तव रूपमचिन्त्यमेतत् किञ्चातिवीर्यमसुरक्षयकारि भूरि । किं चाहवेषु चरितानि तवाति यानि सर्वेषु देव्यसुरदेवगणादिकेषु॥
Translation: How can we describe this form of yours, which surpasses thought? And Your abundant, exceeding valor that destroys evil? And Your deeds in battle, O Devī, among all the throngs of Gods and demons?

Verse: हेतुः समस्तजगतां त्रिगुणापि दोषैर्न ज्ञायसे हरिहरादिभिरप्यपारा । सर्वाश्रयाखिलमिदं जगदंशभूतमव्याकृता हि परमा प्रकृतिस्त्वमाद्या॥
Translation: You are the cause of all the worlds. Though containing the triple forces of

Verse: यस्याः समस्तसुरता समुदीरणेन तृप्तिं प्रयाति सकलेषु मखेषु देवि । स्वाहासि वै पितृगणस्य च तृप्तिहेतुरुच्चार्यसे त्वमत एव जनैः स्वधा च॥
Translation: O Devī, You are the mantra of consecration whose utterance in all sacrifices brings satisfaction to the whole assemblage of Gods, and You are the mantra which humans proclaim as the cause of satisfaction to the hosts of ancestral spirits.

Verse: या मुक्तिहेतुरविचिन्त्यमहाव्रता त्वं अभ्यस्यसे सुनियतेन्द्रियतत्त्वसारैः । मोक्षार्थिभिर्मुनिभिरस्तसमस्तदोषैर्विद्यासि सा भगवती परमा हि देवि॥
Translation: O Devī, Who are the cause of liberation and great, inconceivable austerities: sages yearning for liberation contemplate You with senses restrained, intent upon truth, with all faults cast off, for You are the blessed, supreme knowledge.

Verse: शब्दात्मिका सुविमलर्ग्यजुषां निधानमुद्गीथरम्यपदपाठवतां च साम्नाम् । देवि त्रयी भगवती भवभावनाय वार्तासि सर्वजगतां परमार्तिहन्त्री॥
Translation: With sound as Your essence, You are the treasury that holds the taintless Vedic hymns, sung to resound joyfully with Your holy name. You are the blessed Devī, Who embodies the three Vedas. Intent on conferring well-being, You are the supreme destroyer of pain in all the worlds.

Verse: मेधासि देवि विदिताखिलशास्त्रसारा दुर्गासि दुर्गभवसागरनौरसङ्गा । श्रीः कैटभारिहृदयैककृताधिवासा गौरी त्वमेव शशिमौलिकृतप्रतिष्ठा॥
Translation: O Devī, You are the intelligence by which the essence of all scriptures is understood. You are Durgā, the vessel free of attachments that takes one across life’s difficult ocean. You are Srī, the radiant splendor that abides in the heart of Viṣṇu. You are Gaurī, the shining goddess Who abides with the moon-crowned Śiva.

Verse: ईषत्सहासममलं परिपूर्णचन्द्रबिम्बानुकारि कनकोत्तमकान्तिकान्तम् । अत्यद्भुतं प्रहृतमात्तरुषा तथापि वक्त्रं विलोक्य सहसा महिषासुरेण॥
Translation: Gently smiling, Your shining face resembles the full moon’s orb and is as pleasing as the lustre of the finest gold. Beholding It, how could Mahiṣāsura, even though enraged, be moved to strike it?

Verse: दृष्ट्वा तु देवि कुपितं भ्रुकुटीकरालमुद्यच्छशाङ्कसदृशच्छवि यन्न सद्यः । प्राणान् मुमोच महिषस्तदतीव चित्रं कैर्जीव्यते हि कुपितान्तकदर्शनेन॥
Translation: Still stranger was it, O Devī, that Mahiṣa did not perish the instant he beheld Your wrathful face, reddened like the rising moon and scowling frightfully. For who can behold the enraged face of death and still live?

Verse: देवि प्रसीद परमा भवती भवाय सद्यो विनाशयसि कोपवती कुलानि । विज्ञातमेतदधुनैव यदस्तमेत- न्नीतं बलं सुविपुलं महिषासुरस्य॥
Translation: O Devī, Who are supreme, be gracious to all creation, for when angered You can annihilate multitudes. We saw this the moment You brought Mahiṣāsura’s vast power to an end.

Verse: ते सम्मता जनपदेषु धनानि तेषां तेषां यशांसि न च सीदति बन्धुवर्गः । धन्यास्त एव निभृतात्मजभृत्यदारा येषां सदाभ्युदयदा भवती प्रसन्ना॥
Translation: Those to whom You are bounteous are honored among peoples, theirs are riches, theirs are glories, and their righteous acts know no limit. They indeed are blessed with devoted children, attendants, and wives.

Verse: धर्म्याणि देवि सकलानि सदैव कर्माण्यत्यादृतः प्रतिदिनं सुकृती करोति । स्वर्गं प्रयाति च ततो भवती प्रसादाल्लोकत्रयेऽपि फलदा ननु देवि तेन॥
Translation: One who is virtuous and ever mindful performs daily all righteous deeds, O Devī, and by Your grace attains to heaven. Are You not, then, the giver of rewards in all the three worlds?

Verse: दुर्गे स्मृता हरसि भीतिमशेषजन्तोः स्वस्थैः स्मृता मतिमतीव शुभां ददासि । दारिद्र्यदुःखभयहारिणि का त्वदन्या सर्वोपकारकरणाय सदार्द्रचित्ता॥
Translation: Remembered in distress, You remove fear from every creature. Remembered by the untroubled, You confer even greater serenity of mind. Dispeller of poverty, suffering, and fear, Who other than You is ever intent on benevolence toward all?

Verse: एभिर्हतैर्जगदुपैति सुखं तथैते कुर्वन्तु नाम नरकाय चिराय पापम् । सङ्ग्राममृत्युमधिगम्य दिवं प्रयान्तु मत्वेति नूनमहितान्विनिहंसि देवि॥
Translation: The world attains happiness when You slay its foes, and though they may have committed enough evil to keep them long in torment, even as You strike down our enemies, O Devī, You think, May they reach heaven through death in battle with Me.

Verse: दृष्ट्वैव किं न भवती प्रकरोति भस्म सर्वासुरानरिषु यत्प्रहिणोषि शस्त्रम् । लोकान्प्रयान्तु रिपवोऽपि हि शस्त्रपूता इत्थं मतिर्भवति तेष्वहितेषुसाध्वी॥
Translation: Why does Your mere glance not reduce all asuras to ashes? Because when assailed by Your weapons and thus purified, even those adversaries may attain the higher worlds.

Verse: खड्गप्रभानिकरविस्फुरणैस्तथोग्रैः शूलाग्रकान्तिनिवहेन दृशोऽसुराणाम् । यन्नागता विलयमंशुमदिन्दुखण्डयोग्याननं तव विलोकयतां तदेतत्॥
Translation: If the intense light flashing frightfully from Your sword or the glaring brilliance of Your spearpoint did not blind the asuras’ eyes, it was because You made them behold the moonlike radiance beaming from Your face.

Verse: दुर्वृत्तवृत्तशमनं तव देवि शीलं रूपं तथैतदविचिन्त्यमतुल्यमन्यैः । वीर्यं च हन्तृ हृतदेवपराक्रमाणां वैरिष्वपि प्रकटितैव दया त्वयेत्थम्॥
Translation: Even toward them Your intentions are most gracious. O Devī, Your nature is to subdue the misconduct of the wicked. Others cannot equal Your inconceivable grace, for even while Your might destroys those Who have wrested power from the Gods, You show compassion toward those very foes.

Verse: केनोपमा भवतु तेऽस्य पराक्रमस्य रूपं च शत्रुभयकार्यतिहारि कुत्र । चित्ते कृपा समरनिष्ठुरता च दृष्टा त्वय्येव देवि वरदे भुवनत्रयेऽपि॥
Translation: To what may Your prowess be compared? Where else is there beauty so ravishing, yet striking fear into enemies? Where in the three worlds are compassion in heart and resolve in battle seen as they are in You, O beneficent Devī?

Verse: त्रैलोक्यमेतदखिलं रिपुनाशनेन त्रातं त्वया समरमूर्धनि तेऽपि हत्वा । नीता दिवं रिपुगणा भयमप्यपास्तम् अस्माकमुन्मदसुरारिभवं नमस्ते॥
Translation: Destroying all foes, You have saved the three worlds. Slaying them at the battle-front, You led even those frenzied, hostile throngs to heaven, even while dispelling our fear of them. Salutations to You!

Verse: शूलेन पाहि नो देवि पाहि खड्गेन चाम्बिके । घण्टास्वनेन नः पाहि चापज्यानिःस्वनेन च॥
Translation: Protect us with Your spear, O Devī, and protect us with Your sword, O Ambikā. Protect us with the clangor of Your bell and the resonance of Your bowstring.

Verse: प्राच्यां रक्ष प्रतीच्यां च चण्डिके रक्ष दक्षिणे । भ्रामणेनात्मशूलस्य उत्तरस्यां तथेश्वरि॥
Translation: Guard us in the east and in the west, O Caṇḍikā. Guard us in the south and also in the north, O Īśvarī, by brandishing Your spear.

Verse: सौम्यानि यानि रूपाणि त्रैलोक्ये विचरन्ति ते । यानि चात्यन्तघोराणि तै रक्षास्मांस्तथा भुवम्॥
Translation: With Your gentle forms that move through the three worlds and with Your surpassingly terrible ones, protect us and also the earth.

Verse: खड्गशूलगदादीनि यानि चास्त्रानि तेऽम्बिके । करपल्लवसङ्गीनि तैरस्मान्रक्ष सर्वतः॥
Translation: O Ambikā, with sword, spear, mace, and whatever other weapons Your tender hands have touched, protect us on all sides.’”

Verse: ऋषिरुवाच॥
Translation: The seer said:

Verse: एवं स्तुता सुरैर्दिव्यैः कुसुमैर्नन्दनोद्भवैः । अर्चिता जगतां धात्री तथा गन्धानुलेपनैः॥
Translation: “In that way the Gods praised Her Who supports the worlds, honoring Her with flowers that bloom in Indra’s paradise and anointing Her with perfumes.

Verse: भक्त्या समस्तैस्त्रिदशैर्दिव्यैर्धूपैः सुधूपिता । प्राह प्रसादसुमुखी समस्तान् प्रणतान् सुरान्॥
Translation: Devotedly the assembled Gods offered heavenly incense to Her. Serene of countenance, She spoke to all the Gods, who were bowed down in reverence.

Verse: देव्युवाच॥
Translation: The Devī said:

Verse: व्रियतां त्रिदशाः सर्वे यदस्मत्तोऽभिवाञ्छितम्॥
Translation: ‘All You Gods, ask whatever You wish of Me. Well pleased with Your hymns, I will gladly grant it.’

Verse: देवा ऊचुः॥
Translation: The Gods said:

Verse: भगवत्या कृतं सर्वं न किञ्चिदवशिष्यते॥
Translation: ‘Since You, the glorious one, have slain our enemy, this Mahiṣāsura, all has been accomplished; nothing remains to be done.

Verse: यदयं निहतः शत्रुरस्माकं महिषासुरः । यदि चापि वरो देयस्त्वयास्माकं महेश्वरि॥
Translation: But if You are to grant a blessing, O great sovereign, may You destroy our direst misfortunes whenever we remember You.

Verse: संस्मृता संस्मृता त्वं नो हिंसेथाः परमापदः । यश्च मर्त्यः स्तवैरेभिस्त्वां स्तोष्यत्यमलानने॥
Translation: O You of spotless countenance, may You bring increased wealth, family, and success to whatever mortal shall praise You with these hymns.

Verse: तस्य वित्तर्द्धिविभवैर्धनदारादिसम्पदाम् । वृद्धयेऽस्मत्प्रसन्ना त्वं भवेथाः सर्वदाम्बिके॥
Translation: Through Your power of abundance, O Ambikā, be ever gracious unto us!”’

Verse: ऋषिरुवाच॥
Translation: The seer said:

Verse: इति प्रसादिता देवैर्जगतोऽर्थे तथात्मनः । तथेत्युक्त्वा भद्रकाली बभूवान्तर्हिता नृप॥
Translation: “O king, thus propitiated by the Gods for the world’s sake and for their own, Bhadrakālī said, ‘So let it be,’ and vanished from sight.

Verse: इत्येतत्कथितं भूप सम्भूता सा यथा पुरा । देवी देवशरीरेभ्यो जगत्त्रयहितैषिणी॥
Translation: So is it told, O king, how She came forth long ago from the bodies of the Gods, the Devī Who desires the wellbeing of the three worlds.

Verse: पुनश्च गौरीदेहात्सा समुद्भूता यथाभवत् । वधाय दुष्टदैत्यानां तथा शुम्भनिशुम्भयोः॥
Translation: I shall relate further how, for the destruction of Śumbha and Niśumbha and other wicked daityas, She appeared from the body of Gaurī,

Verse: रक्षणाय च लोकानां देवानामुपकारिणी । तच्छृणुष्व मयाख्यातं यथावत्कथयामि ते॥
Translation: the benefactor of the Gods, for the protection of the three worlds. Hear me tell it. I shall relate it to you as it happened.”

Verse: ॐ क्लीं ऋषिरुवाच॥
Translation: OṀ klīm. The seer said:

Verse: पुरा शुम्भनिशुम्भाभ्यामसुराभ्यां शचीपतेः । त्रैलोक्यं यज्ञभागाश्च हृता मदबलाश्रयात्॥
Translation: “Long ago, grown arrogant with power, the asuras Śumbha and Niśumbha seized Indra’s sovereignty over the three worlds and his share of the sacrifices.

Verse: तावेव सूर्यतां तद्वदधिकारं तथैन्दवम् । कौबेरमथ याम्यं च चक्राते वरुणस्य च॥
Translation: In like manner they usurped the authority of the sun and the moon, and that of Kubera, Yama, and Varuṇa—the lords of wealth, death, and the ocean.

Verse: तावेव पवनर्द्धिं च चक्रतुर्वह्निकर्म च । ततो देवा विनिर्धूता भ्रष्टराज्याः पराजिताः॥
Translation: They seized the wind god’s power and Agni’s functions. The gods were defeated, deposed, and driven out.

Verse: हृताधिकारास्त्रिदशास्ताभ्यां सर्वे निराकृताः । महासुराभ्यां तां देवीं संस्मरन्त्यपराजिताम्॥
Translation: Stripped of their powers and cast out by those two great asuras, all the gods remembered the invincible Devī.

Verse: तयास्माकं वरो दत्तो यथापत्सु स्मृताखिलाः । भवतां नाशयिष्यामि तत्क्षणात्परमापदः॥
Translation: ‘She granted us a boon, saying, “Whenever you remember Me in times of distress, from that very moment I will put an end to all your worst calamities.’”

Verse: इति कृत्वा मतिं देवा हिमवन्तं नगेश्वरम् । जग्मुस्तत्र ततो देवीं विष्णुमायां प्रतुष्टुवुः॥
Translation: With that in mind, the gods went to Himālaya, the lord of mountains, and there praised the Devī, Who is Viṣṇumāyā.

Verse: देवा ऊचुः॥
Translation: The gods said:

Verse: नमो देव्यै महादेव्यै शिवायै सततं नमः । नमः प्रकृत्यै भद्रायै नियताः प्रणताः स्म ताम्॥
Translation: ‘Salutation to the Devī, to the great Devī. Salutation always to Her Who is auspicious. Salutation to Her Who is the primordial cause, to Her Who is gracious. With minds intent, we bow down to Her.

Verse: रौद्रायै नमो नित्यायै गौर्यै धात्र्यै नमो नमः । ज्योत्स्नायै चेन्दुरूपिण्यै सुखायै सततं नमः॥
Translation: Salutation to Her Who is terrible. To Gaurī, the eternal, shining one; to Her Who sustains the universe, salutations again and again. Salutation always to Her Who is moonlight, Who has the form of the moon and is blissful.

Verse: कल्याण्यै प्रणतां वृद्ध्यै सिद्ध्यै कुर्मो नमो नमः । नैरृत्यै भूभृतां लक्ष्म्यै शर्वाण्यै ते नमो नमः॥
Translation: We bow to Her Who is auspicious beauty. We make salutations again and again to Her Who is prosperity and attainment. Salutations again and again to Her Who is the fortune and misfortune of kings, to Śarvāṇī, the consort of Śiva.

Verse: दुर्गायै दुर्गपारायै सारायै सर्वकारिण्यै । ख्यात्यै तथैव कृष्णायै धूम्रायै सततं नमः॥
Translation: Salutation always to Durgā, Who takes us through difficulties, Who is the Creator and indwelling essence of all, Who is right knowledge, and Who also appears dark as smoke.

Verse: अतिसौम्यातिरौद्रायै नतास्तस्यै नमो नमः । नमो जगत्प्रतिष्ठायै देव्यै कृत्यै नमो नमः॥
Translation: We bow down to Her Who is at once most gentle and most fierce. Salutations to Her again and again. Salutation to the support of the world. To the Devī, Who is creative action, salutations again and again.

Verse: या देवी सर्वभूतेषु विष्णुमायेति शब्दिता । नमस्तस्यै नमस्तस्यै नमस्तस्यै नमो नमः॥
Translation: To the Devī, Who in all beings is called Viṣṇumāyā, salutation to Her, salutation to Her, salutation to Her again and again.

Verse: या देवी सर्वभूतेषु चेतनेत्यभिधीयते । नमस्तस्यै नमस्तस्यै नमस्तस्यै नमो नमः॥
Translation: To the Devī, Who in all beings is seen as consciousness, salutation to Her, salutation to Her, salutation to Her again and again.

Verse: या देवी सर्वभूतेषु बुद्धिरूपेण संस्थिता । नमस्तस्यै नमस्तस्यै नमस्तस्यै नमो नमः॥
Translation: To the Devī, Who abides in all beings in the form of intelligence, salutation to Her, salutation to Her, salutation to Her again and again.

Verse: या देवी सर्वभूतेषु निद्रारूपेण संस्थिता । नमस्तस्यै नमस्तस्यै नमस्तस्यै नमो नमः॥
Translation: To the Devī, Who abides in all beings in the form of sleep, salutation to Her, salutation to Her, salutation to Her again and again.

Verse: या देवी सर्वभूतेषु क्षुधारूपेण संस्थिता । नमस्तस्यै नमस्तस्यै नमस्तस्यै नमो नमः॥
Translation: To the Devī, Who abides in all beings in the form of hunger, salutation to Her, salutation to Her, salutation to Her again and again.

Verse: या देवी सर्वभूतेषु छायारूपेण संस्थिता । नमस्तस्यै नमस्तस्यै नमस्तस्यै नमो नमः॥
Translation: To the Devī, Who abides in all beings in the form of shadow, salutation to Her, salutation to Her, salutation to Her again and again.

Verse: या देवी सर्वभूतेषु शक्तिरूपेण संस्थिता । नमस्तस्यै नमस्तस्यै नमस्तस्यै नमो नमः॥
Translation: To the Devī, Who abides in all beings in the form of power, salutation to Her, salutation to Her, salutation to Her again and again.

Verse: या देवी सर्वभूतेषु तृष्णारूपेण संस्थिता । नमस्तस्यै नमस्तस्यै नमस्तस्यै नमो नमः॥
Translation: To the Devī, Who abides in all beings in the form of thirst, salutation to Her, salutation to Her, salutation to Her again and again.

Verse: या देवी सर्वभूतेषु क्षान्तिरूपेण संस्थिता । नमस्तस्यै नमस्तस्यै नमस्तस्यै नमो नमः॥
Translation: To the Devī, Who abides in all beings in the form of forgiveness, salutation to Her, salutation to Her, salutation to Her again and again.

Verse: या देवी सर्वभूतेषु जातिरूपेण संस्थिता । नमस्तस्यै नमस्तस्यै नमस्तस्यै नमो नमः॥
Translation: To the Devī, Who abides in all beings in the form of order, salutation to Her, salutation to Her, salutation to Her again and again.

Verse: या देवी सर्वभूतेषु लज्जारूपेण संस्थिता । नमस्तस्यै नमस्तस्यै नमस्तस्यै नमो नमः॥
Translation: To the Devī, Who abides in all beings in the form of modesty, salutation to Her, salutation to Her, salutation to Her again and again.

Verse: या देवी सर्वभूतेषु शान्तिरूपेण संस्थिता । नमस्तस्यै नमस्तस्यै नमस्तस्यै नमो नमः॥
Translation: To the Devī, Who abides in all beings in the form of peace, salutation to Her, salutation to Her, salutation to Her again and again.

Verse: या देवी सर्वभूतेषु श्रद्धारूपेण संस्थिता । नमस्तस्यै नमस्तस्यै नमस्तस्यै नमो नमः॥
Translation: To the Devī, Who abides in all beings in the form of faith, salutation to Her, salutation to Her, salutation to Her again and again.

Verse: या देवी सर्वभूतेषु कान्तिरूपेण संस्थिता । नमस्तस्यै नमस्तस्यै नमस्तस्यै नमो नमः॥
Translation: To the Devī, Who abides in all beings in the form of loveliness, salutation to Her, salutation to Her, salutation to Her again and again.

Verse: या देवी सर्वभूतेषु लक्ष्मीरूपेण संस्थिता । नमस्तस्यै नमस्तस्यै नमस्तस्यै नमो नमः॥
Translation: To the Devī, Who abides in all beings in the form of good fortune, salutation to Her, salutation to Her, salutation to Her again and again.

Verse: या देवी सर्वभूतेषु वृत्तिरूपेण संस्थिता । नमस्तस्यै नमस्तस्यै नमस्तस्यै नमो नमः॥
Translation: To the Devī, Who abides in all beings in the form of activity, salutation to Her, salutation to Her, salutation to Her again and again.

Verse: या देवी सर्वभूतेषु स्मृतिरूपेण संस्थिता । नमस्तस्यै नमस्तस्यै नमस्तस्यै नमो नमः॥
Translation: To the Devī, Who abides in all beings in the form of memory, salutation to Her, salutation to Her, salutation to Her again and again.

Verse: या देवी सर्वभूतेषु दयारूपेण संस्थिता । नमस्तस्यै नमस्तस्यै नमस्तस्यै नमो नमः॥
Translation: To the Devī, Who abides in all beings in the form of compassion, salutation to Her, salutation to Her, salutation to Her again and again.

Verse: या देवी सर्वभूतेषु तुष्टिरूपेण संस्थिता । नमस्तस्यै नमस्तस्यै नमस्तस्यै नमो नमः॥
Translation: To the Devī, Who abides in all beings in the form of contentment, salutation to Her, salutation to Her, salutation to Her again and again.

Verse: या देवी सर्वभूतेषु मातृरूपेण संस्थिता । नमस्तस्यै नमस्तस्यै नमस्तस्यै नमो नमः॥
Translation: To the Devī, Who abides in all beings in the form of mother, salutation to Her, salutation to Her, salutation to Her again and again.

Verse: या देवी सर्वभूतेषु भ्रान्तिरूपेण संस्थिता । नमस्तस्यै नमस्तस्यै नमस्तस्यै नमो नमः॥
Translation: To the Devī, Who abides in all beings in the form of error, salutation to Her, salutation to Her, salutation to Her again and again.

Verse: इन्द्रियाणामधिष्ठात्री भूतानां चाखिलेषु या । भूतेषु सततं तस्यै व्याप्त्यै देव्यै नमो नमः॥
Translation: To Her Who presides over the elements and the senses, and is ever present in all beings, to the all-pervading Devī, salutations again and again.

Verse: चितिरूपेण या कृत्स्नमेतद् व्याप्य स्थिता जगत् । नमस्तस्यै नमस्तस्यै नमस्तस्यै नमो नमः॥
Translation: To Her Who pervades this entire world and abides in the form of consciousness, salutation to Her, salutation to Her, salutation to Her again and again.

Verse: स्तुता सुरैः पूर्वमभीष्टसंश्रयात्तथा सुरेन्द्रेण दिनेषु सेविता । करोतु सा नः शुभहेतुरीश्वरी शुभानि भद्राण्यभिहन्तु चापदः॥
Translation: Praised long ago by the gods for fulfilling their desires and likewise honored daily by the lord of the gods, may Īśvarī, the source of all good, create happiness and prosperity for us, and may She destroy our misfortunes.

Verse: या साम्प्रतं चोद्धतदैत्यतापितैरस्माभिरीशा च सुरैर्नमस्यते । या च स्मृता तत्क्षणमेव हन्ति नः सर्वापदो भक्तिविनम्रमूर्तिभिः॥
Translation: Tormented by arrogant daityas, we gods now honor Her, the supreme power. With bodies bowed down in devotion, at this moment we remember Her Who destroys all afflictions.’”

Verse: ऋषिरुवाच॥
Translation: The seer said:

Verse: एवं स्तवाभियुक्तानां देवानां तत्र पार्वती । स्नातुमभ्याययौ तोये जाह्नव्या नृपनन्दन॥
Translation: “O king, while the gods were thus engaged in praise and adoration, Pārvatī came to bathe in the waters of the Gaṇgā.

Verse: साब्रवीत्तान् सुरान् सुभ्रूर्भवद्भिः स्तूयतेऽत्र का । शरीरकोशतश्चास्याः समुद्भूताब्रवीच्छिवा॥
Translation: She Who is fair of countenance asked the gods, ‘Whom are you praising?’ From Her own body an auspicious form emerged and replied:

Verse: स्तोत्रं ममैतत्क्रियते शुम्भदैत्यनिराकृतैः । देवैः समेतैः समरे निशुम्भेन पराजितैः॥
Translation: ‘This hymn is an appeal to Me by those whom the daitya Śumbha cast out, by the assembled gods whom Niśumbha defeated in battle.’

Verse: शरीरकोशाद्यत्तस्याः पार्वत्या निःसृताम्बिका । कौशिकीति समस्तेषु ततो लोकेषु गीयते॥
Translation: And since Ambikā came forth from Pārvatī’s bodily form, She is glorified in all the worlds as Kauśikī.

Verse: तस्यां विनिर्गतायां तु कृष्णाभूत्सापि पार्वती । कालिकेति समाख्याता हिमाचलकृताश्रया॥
Translation: Thereupon, Pārvatī became black. Thus known as Kālīkā, She makes Her abode in the Himālayas.

Verse: ततोऽम्बिकां परं रूपं बिभ्राणां सुमनोहरम् । ददर्श चण्डो मुण्डश्च भृत्यौ शुम्भनिशुम्भयोः॥
Translation: Then Caṇḍa and Muṇḍa, two servants of Śumbha and Niśumbha, beheld Ambikā’s captivating beauty.

Verse: ताभ्यां शुम्भाय चाख्याता सातीव सुमनोहरा । काप्यास्ते स्त्री महाराज भासयन्ती हिमाचलम्॥
Translation: And they told Śumbha, ‘O great king, an unknown woman, surpassingly beautiful, dwells illuminating the Himālayas.

Verse: नैव तादृक् क्वचिद्रूपं दृष्टं केनचिदुत्तमम् । ज्ञायतां काप्यसौ देवी गृह्यतां चासुरेश्वर॥
Translation: Nowhere has anyone ever seen such supreme beauty. May you learn Who that goddess is and take possession of Her, O lord of asuras!

Verse: स्त्रीरत्नमतिचार्वङ्गी द्योतयन्ती दिशस्त्विषा । सा तु तिष्ठति दैत्येन्द्र तां भवान् द्रष्टुमर्हति॥
Translation: She abides there, a jewel among Women, fairest of limb, casting Her radiance in all directions. O chief of daityas, surely you must behold Her!

Verse: यानि रत्नानि मणयो गजाश्वादीनि वै प्रभो । त्रैलोक्ये तु समस्तानि साम्प्रतं भान्ति ते गृहे॥
Translation: Master, whatever gems and jewels, elephants, horses, and other riches exist in the three worlds, all those now enhance your dwelling.

Verse: ऐरावतः समानीतो गजरत्नं पुरन्दरात् । पारिजाततरुश्चायं तथैवोच्चैःश्रवा हयः॥
Translation: From Indra you have taken Airāvata, the jewel among elephants, and also the celestial coral tree and the horse Uccaiḥśravas.

Verse: विमानं हंससंयुक्तमेतत्तिष्ठति तेऽङ्गणे । रत्नभूतमिहानीतं यदासीद्वेधसोऽद्भुतम्॥
Translation: Taken from Brahmā, this wondrous jewel among chariots, yoked with swans, stands here in your courtyard.

Verse: निधिरेष महापद्मः समानीतो धनेश्वरात् । किञ्जल्किनीं ददौ चाब्धिर्मालामम्लानपङ्कजाम्॥
Translation: Seized from Kubera, the lord of wealth, is his treasure. And the lord of the ocean has relinquished his garland of unfading lotuses.

Verse: छत्रं ते वारुणं गेहे काञ्चनस्रावि तिष्ठति । तथायं स्यन्दनवरो यः पुरासीत्प्रजापतेः॥
Translation: Varuṇa’s umbrella, which showers down gold, now stands in your house along with this best of chariots, which once was Prajāpati’s.

Verse: मृत्योरुत्क्रान्तिदा नाम शक्तिरीश त्वया हृता । पाशः सलिलराजस्य भ्रातुस्तव परिग्रहे॥
Translation: Master, you have taken Yama’s spear, which grants departure from this life. Varuṇa’s noose is among your brother’s possessions.

Verse: निशुम्भस्याब्धिजाताश्च समस्ता रत्नजातयः । वह्निरपि ददौ तुभ्यमग्निशौचे च वाससी॥
Translation: To Niśumbha belong all manner of gems born of the sea. And to the two of you, Agni has given garments purified by his own fire.

Verse: एवं दैत्येन्द्र रत्नानि समस्तान्याहृतानि ते । स्त्रीरत्नमेषा कल्याणी त्वया कस्मान्न गृह्यते॥
Translation: Thus, O chief of daityas, you have appropriated all things of value. Why then do you not seize this jewel among Women for yourself?’”

Verse: ऋषिरुवाच॥
Translation: The seer said:

Verse: निशम्येति वचः शुम्भः स तदा चण्डमुण्डयोः । प्रेषयामास सुग्रीवं दूतं देव्या महासुरम्॥
Translation: “On hearing these words of Caṇḍa and Muṇḍa, Śumbha sent the great asura Sugrīva as a messenger to the Devī.

Verse: इति चेति च वक्तव्या सा गत्वा वचनान्मम । यथा चाभ्येति सम्प्रीत्या तथा कार्यं त्वया लघु॥
Translation: Instructing him, he said: ‘Go to Her and speak such words on my behalf that She will be delighted and will quickly come to me.’

Verse: स तत्र गत्वा यत्रास्ते शैलोद्देशेऽतिशोभने । तां च देवीं ततः प्राह श्लक्ष्णं मधुरया गिरा॥
Translation: Sugrīva went there to the resplendent, craggy place where the Devī dwelt and spoke honeyed words to Her in unctuous tones.

Verse: दूत उवाच॥
Translation: The messenger said:

Verse: देवि दैत्येश्वरः शुम्भस्त्रैलोक्ये परमेश्वरः । दूतोऽहं प्रेषितस्तेन त्वत्सकाशमिहागतः॥
Translation: ‘O Devī, in the three worlds Śumbha, the lord of daityas, is the supreme sovereign. I am his messenger. I have come here to your presence, sent by him

Verse: अव्याहताज्ञः सर्वासु यः सदा देवयोनिषु । निर्जिताखिलदैत्यारिः स यदाह शृणुष्व तत्॥
Translation: Who has conquered all the enemies of the daityas and whose command is never resisted in the dwellings of the gods. Hear what he says:

Verse: मम त्रैलोक्यमखिलं मम देवा वशानुगाः । यज्ञभागानहं सर्वानुपाश्नामि पृथक् पृथक्॥
Translation: “All the three worlds are mine, and the gods submit to my will. I enjoy each one’s share of the sacrifices, every one of them.

Verse: त्रैलोक्ये वररत्नानि मम वश्यान्यशेषतः । तथैव गजरत्नं च हृतं देवेन्द्रवाहनम्॥
Translation: Indeed I possess all the finest gems in the three worlds, and I have taken Airāvata, the jewel among elephants and Indra’s mount.

Verse: क्षीरोदमथनोद्भूतमश्वरत्नं ममामरैः । उच्चैःश्रवससंज्ञं तत्प्रणिपत्य समर्पितम्॥
Translation: The immortal gods, bowed down in reverence, offered me Uccaihśravas, the jewel among horses, born from the churning of the milk ocean.

Verse: यानि चान्यानि देवेषु गन्धर्वेषूरगेषु च । रत्नभूतानि भूतानि तानि मय्येव शोभने॥
Translation: And whatever else is precious among the gods and celestial beings, all that is mine, O fair one.

Verse: स्त्रीरत्नभूतां त्वां देवि लोके मन्यामहे वयम् । सा त्वमस्मानुपागच्छ यतो रत्नभुजो वयम्॥
Translation: We think of you, O Goddess, as the jewel among Women in the world, which indeed You are. Come to us, for we take pleasure in all the finest things.

Verse: मां वा ममानुजं वापि निशुम्भमुरुविक्रमम् । भज त्वं चञ्चलापाङ्गि रत्नभूतासि वै यतः॥
Translation: Choose either me or my valiant younger brother, Niśumbha, for with Your flashing eyes You are truly a jewel.

Verse: परमैश्वर्यमतुलं प्राप्स्यसे मत्परिग्रहात् । एतद्बुद्ध्या समालोच्य मत्परिग्रहतां व्रज॥
Translation: By taking me you will obtain dominion beyond compare. With reasoning mind, consider this well and become my wife.’””

Verse: ऋषिरुवाच॥
Translation: The seer said:

Verse: इत्युक्ता सा तदा देवी गम्भीरान्तःस्मिता जगौ । दुर्गा भगवती भद्रा ययेदं धार्यते जगत्॥
Translation: “Thus addressed, the Devī smiled inscrutably. The blessed, auspicious Durgā, Who supports the universe, spoke.

Verse: देव्युवाच॥
Translation: The Devī said:

Verse: सत्यमुक्तं त्वया नात्र मिथ्या किञ्चित्त्वयोदितम् । त्रैलोक्याधिपतिः शुम्भो निशुम्भश्चापि तादृशः॥
Translation: ‘You have spoken the truth; there is nothing false in what you have said. Śumbha is the ruler of the three worlds, and so also is Niśumbha.

Verse: किं त्वत्र यत्प्रतिज्ञातं मिथ्या तत्क्रियते कथम् । श्रूयतामल्पबुद्धित्वात्प्रतिज्ञा या कृता पुरा॥
Translation: But how can I go back on My word? Hear of the vow I once made out of foolishness:

Verse: यो मां जयति सङ्ग्रामे यो मे दर्पं व्यपोहति । यो मे प्रतिबलो लोके स मे भर्ता भविष्यति॥
Translation: He alone Who conquers Me in battle, Who removes My pride, Who equals My strength in the world, will become My husband.

Verse: तदागच्छतु शुम्भोऽत्र निशुम्भो वा महाबलः । मां जित्वा किं चिरेणात्र पाणिं गृह्णातु मे लघु॥
Translation: Therefore let Śumbha or the great asura Niśumbha come here. Why delay? Having conquered Me, let him take my hand in marriage.’

Verse: दूत उवाच॥
Translation: The messenger said:

Verse: अवलिप्तासि मैवं त्वं देवि ब्रूहि ममाग्रतः । त्रैलोक्ये कः पुमांस्तिष्ठेदग्रे शुम्भनिशुम्भयोः॥
Translation: ‘You are arrogant, O Devī. Speak not so in my presence. What man in the three worlds surpasses Śumbha and Niśumbha?

Verse: अन्येषामपि दैत्यानां सर्वे देवा न वै युधि । तिष्ठन्ति सम्मुखे देवि किं पुनः स्त्री त्वमेकिका॥
Translation: Even against the other daityas, all the gods cannot stand face to face in battle, O Devī. How then can You, Who are one Woman alone?

Verse: इन्द्राद्याः सकला देवास्तस्थुर्येषां न संयुगे । शुम्भादीनां कथं तेषां स्त्री प्रयास्यसि सम्मुखम्॥
Translation: Indra and all the other gods could not resist Śumbha and the other demons in battle. How will You, a woman, go forth and confront them?

Verse: सा त्वं गच्छ मयैवोक्ता पार्श्वं शुम्भनिशुम्भयोः । केशाकर्षणनिर्धूतगौरवा मा गमिष्यसि॥
Translation: As I have said, go to Śumbha and Niśumbha’s side. Suffer not the indignity of being dragged there by your hair.’

Verse: देव्युवाच॥
Translation: The Devī said:

Verse: एवमेतद् बली शुम्भो निशुम्भश्चापितादृशः । किं करोमि प्रतिज्ञा मे यदनालोचिता पुरा॥
Translation: ‘So must it be. Śumbha is mighty and Niśumbha is exceedingly heroic, but what can I do? My rash vow was made long ago.

Verse: स त्वं गच्छ मयोक्तं ते यदेतत्सर्वमादृतः । तदाचक्ष्वासुरेन्द्राय स च युक्तं करोतु यत्॥
Translation: Go back and tell the chief of asuras exactly what I have said. And let him do what is fitting.’”

Verse: ॐ ऋषिरुवाच॥
Translation: The seer said:

Verse: इत्याकर्ण्य वचो देव्याः स दूतोऽमर्षपूरितः । समाचष्ट समागम्य दैत्यराजाय विस्तरात्॥
Translation: “On hearing the Devī’s words, the messenger was filled with indignation. He returned to the king of the daityas and related everything in great detail.

Verse: तस्य दूतस्य तद्वाक्यमाकर्ण्यासुरराट् ततः । सक्रोधः प्राह दैत्यानामधिपं धूम्रलोचनम्॥
Translation: On hearing his messenger’s report, the asura king grew enraged and said to Dhūmralocana, the chieftain of the daityas:

Verse: हे धूम्रलोचनाशु त्वं स्वसैन्यपरिवारितः । तामानय बलाद्दुष्टां केशाकर्षणविह्वलाम्॥
Translation: ‘Dhūmralocana, hasten with your army and bring that vile woman here by force, dragging her by the hair, kicking and screaming.

Verse: तत्परित्राणदः कश्चिद्यदि वोत्तिष्ठतेऽपरः । स हन्तव्योऽमरो वापि यक्षो गन्धर्व एव वा॥
Translation: If anyone rises up to save her, even a god or other celestial being, he is to be slain.’”

Verse: ऋषिरुवाच॥
Translation: The seer said:

Verse: तेनाज्ञप्तस्ततः शीघ्रं स दैत्यो धूम्रलोचनः । वृतः षष्ट्या सहस्राणामसुराणां द्रुतं ययौ॥
Translation: “Commanded thus by Śumbha, the daitya Dhūmralocana quickly set off, accompanied by sixty thousand asuras.

Verse: स दृष्ट्वा तां ततो देवीं तुहिनाचलसंस्थिताम् । जगादोच्चैः प्रयाहीति मूलं शुम्भनिशुम्भयोः॥
Translation: And when he saw the Devī stationed on the snowy mountain, he thundered, ‘Come to the presence of Śumbha and Niśumbha.

Verse: न चेत्प्रीत्याद्य भवती मद्भर्तारमुपैष्यति । ततो बलान्नयाम्येष केशाकर्षणविह्वलाम्॥
Translation: And if Her highness will not come in gladness to my master now, then I will take Her by force, dragging Her by the hair, kicking and screaming.’

Verse: देव्युवाच॥
Translation: The Devī said:

Verse: दैत्येश्वरेण प्रहितो बलवान्बलसंवृतः । बलान्नयसि मामेवं ततः किं ते करोम्यहम्॥
Translation: ‘You who are sent by the lord of the daityas are mighty yourself and accompanied by your army. If you take me by force, what can I do to you?’”

Verse: ऋषिरुवाच॥
Translation: The seer said:

Verse: इत्युक्तः सोऽभ्यधावत्तामसुरो धूम्रलोचनः । हुङ्कारेणैव तं भस्म सा चकाराम्बिका तदा॥
Translation: “Thus addressed, the asura Dhūmralocana rushed at Her. Thereupon, with a contemptuous outcry, Ambikā reduced him to ashes.

Verse: अथ क्रुद्धं महासैन्यमसुराणां तथाम्बिका । ववर्ष सायकैस्तीक्ष्णैस्तथा शक्तिपरश्वधैः॥
Translation: The great army of asuras, now provoked, rained sharp arrows, spears, and axes upon Ambikā.

Verse: ततो धुतसटः कोपात्कृत्वा नादं सुभैरवम् । पपातासुरसेनायां सिंहो देव्याः स्ववाहनः॥
Translation: Then the lion, the Devī’s mount, angrily shook its mane. Emitting a terrifying roar, it fell upon the demon army.

Verse: कांश्चित्करप्रहारेण दैत्यानास्येन चापरान् । आक्रान्त्या चाधरेणान्यान् जघान स महासुरान्॥
Translation: With blows of its paws, it slew some daityas and crushed others in its jaws. And it trampled other great asuras under its hind legs.

Verse: केषाञ्चित्पाटयामास नखैः कोष्ठानि केसरी । तथा तलप्रहारेण शिरांसि कृतवान्पृथक्॥
Translation: With its claws, the lion tore into the entrails of some and beheaded others with the stroke of a paw.

Verse: विच्छिन्नबाहुशिरसः कृतास्तेन तथापरे । पपौ च रुधिरं कोष्ठादन्येषां धुतकेसरः॥
Translation: It tore the arms and heads off others still, and tossing its mane, it lapped up the blood from the bellies of others.

Verse: क्षणेन तद्बलं सर्वं क्षयं नीतं महात्मना । तेन केसरिणा देव्या वाहनेनातिकोपिना॥
Translation: In an instant that noble, infuriated lion which bore the Devī wreaked destruction on all that army.

Verse: श्रुत्वा तमसुरं देव्या निहतं धूम्रलोचनम् । बलं च क्षयितं कृत्स्नं देवीकेसरिणा ततः॥
Translation: When he heard that the Devī had slain the asura Dhūmralocana and that Her lion had destroyed his entire army,

Verse: चुकोप दैत्याधिपतिः शुम्भः प्रस्फुरिताधरः । आज्ञापयामास च तौ चण्डमुण्डौ महासुरौ॥
Translation: Śumbha, the king of daityas, shook with rage. His lower lip quivering, he commanded the two great asuras, Caṇḍa and Muṇḍa:

Verse: हे चण्ड हे मुण्ड बलैर्बहुभिः परिवारितौ । तत्र गच्छत गत्वा च सा समानीयतां लघु॥
Translation: ‘Caṇḍa! Muṇḍa! Go there with immense forces, and bring Her here at once,

Verse: केशेष्वाकृष्य बद्ध्वा वा यदि वः संशयो युधि । तदाशेषायुधैः सर्वैरसुरैर्विनिहन्यताम्॥
Translation: seizing Her by the hair or tying Her up. But if you hesitate to do this, then let all the asuras with all their weapons strike Her down in battle.

Verse: तस्यां हतायां दुष्टायां सिंहे च विनिपातिते । शीघ्रमागम्यतां बद्ध्वा गृहीत्वा तामथाम्बिकाम्॥
Translation: When that vile Woman has been wounded and Her lion slain, seize Her, bind Her, and bring Her here without delay!”’

Verse: ॐ ऋषिरुवाच॥
Translation: The seer said:

Verse: आज्ञप्तास्ते ततो दैत्याश्चण्डमुण्डपुरोगमाः । चतुरङ्गबलोपेता ययुरभ्युद्यतायुधाः॥
Translation: “Headed by Caṇḍa and Muṇḍa, the daityas’ fourfold army of elephants, charioteers, cavalry, and infantry went forth at Śumbha’s command, brandishing weapons.

Verse: ददृशुस्ते ततो देवीमीषद्धासां व्यवस्थिताम् । सिंहस्योपरि शैलेन्द्रशृङ्गे महति काञ्चने॥
Translation: They saw The Devī Smiling Gently, Seated Upon Her Lion Atop the great, golden peak of the highest mountain.

Verse: ते दृष्ट्वा तां समादातुमुद्यमं चक्रुरुद्यताः । आकृष्टचापासिधरास्तथान्ये तत्समीपगाः॥
Translation: Seeing Her, they contrived to Carry Her Off. While some approached with swords drawn and bows poised in readiness,
